explanation: Dating back to the early days of Cisco IOS, for numbered ACLs configured with global access-list commands, to delete one line from an ACL, you had to begin by deleting the ACL with the no access-list number global command. Then, you would configure access-list global commands to reconfigure all the lines you wanted in the ACL, in the correct order. Alternatively, using the same configuration process IOS supports for named ACLs to configure numbered ACLs. That process supports ACL configuration mode and line numbers, allowing you to remove one line in the ACL. To do so, once in ACL configuration mode for the ACL, the no line-number command deletes one line of the ACL.

answerChoices.Text: Delete the entire ACL and reconfigure the three global access-list commands that should remain in the ACL.
Delete the second line from the ACL using the no access-list global command.
Enter ACL configuration mode for the ACL and delete only the second line with the no sequence-number command.
Delete the last three lines using no access-list global commands and then add the last two statements with additional access-list global commands.

questionText:
Which named ACLs in the exhibit provide the equivalent logic as this numbered ACL?

access-list 101 deny tcp any host 10.1.2.3 eq telnet
access-list 101 deny tcp any host 10.1.2.3 eq ftp
access-list 101 deny tcp any host 10.1.2.3 eq www
access-list 101 permit ip any any
explanation:
When converting a numbered ACL to a named ACL, it first must be determined which type of ACL is being converted; in this case, since the number used is 101, it is an extended ACL. This is then used to perform the initial creation of the ACL with the ip access-list extended name command; this will enter the user into extended named ACL configuration mode. Note that two of the possible named ACLs in the exhibit do not use this command, but instead use a non-existent access-list extended name command (that is, without beginning with ip).

	The permit and deny commands in a named ACL look much like the numbered ACL equivalent, and can be created by removing the access-list 101 from the commands in this case. A close examination of the correct answer text in the exhibit shows the exact same text as shown in the question for the last four lines of the ACL, except that the access-list 101 text does not appear.
comments:
12/20 - query to Au

1/19 - ok as-is, 1/3, 9/13 - query to Au

questionText: A junior-level engineer has been given the task of configuring an ACL on a router; she was told that the port that should be blocked is UDP 69. Which access-list command keyword could be used in place of this port number when configured?
explanation: There are a number of common application port numbers that can be configured using an access-list command keyword in place of the actual port number. UDP port number 69 is used for Trivial File Transfer Protocol, which can be configured (as is shown in the configuration) using the keyword tftp.

questionText:
ACL 105 (shown below) has been configured but not enabled on an interface. Users continue to generate traffic that would match the first ACE in the ACL if it were enabled on the router's G0/0/1 interface in the outbound direction. The answers listing text you might expect to see in the output of the show access-list command on this router related to the first ACE in the ACL. Which answer displays the correct detail and formatting expected in this case?


access-list 105 deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www
access-list 105 deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq 443
access-list 105 permit ip any any
…
explanation:
First, look to the left side of the answers. Some list line numbers and some do not. On IOS and IOS XE, the show access-list command lists the line numbers used for each ACE in an ACL – even for ACLs defined by numbered ACL access-list global commands. The configuration shown as part of the question shows numbered ACL configuration. By default, IOS assigns line numbers starting at 10 for increments of 10, so the first line of the ACL (represented by the answers) will use line number 10. These facts rule out two answers as incorrect.

Next, look at the right side of the answers, some of which list match counts and others do not. The show access-list command on IOS and IOS XE lists statistics for matches of each line of the ACL once you enable it on an interface. Because the ACL is not enabled, the ACL has not matched any packets, and the command would not list any statistics. That fact rules out two remaining answers, leaving one correct answer. That correct answer lists line number 10 with no matches counter statistics at the end of the line.

answerChoices.Text: deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www (18 matches)
10 deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www (18 matches)
10 deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www (0 matches)

questionText: Which of the listed commands would IOS accept to create a new named extended IP ACL? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The names in the command used to create named ACLs (the ip access-list global command) must conform to these rules:


	Must begin with a letter
	It cannot contain quotation marks or spaces
	Is case sensitive (e.g., GracieMay is a different name than Graciemay.)


Of the different answers, four conform to those rules. One incorrect answer uses quotes, and another uses a space.

Additionally, the question asks for commands that create an extended named ACL. Of the four answers whose names follow the naming convention, two use the standard rather than the extended keyword, creating a standard named ACL.  Only the two correct answers create extended ACLs.

questionText: An engineer configures an ACL on a router running IOS (not IOS XE), but forgets to save the configuration. At that point, which of the following commands display the IPv4 ACL along with line numbers? (Choose two answers.)
explanation: When using IOS, the show ip access-lists and show access-lists commands both display the configuration of IPv4 access lists, including ACL line numbers. However, with IOS, neither the show running-config nor show startup-config commands list the ACL line numbers. Note that in this case, because the engineer did not save the configuration, the startup-config file would not contain the ACL configuration at all.

questionText: An engineer configures new ACL 105 and enables it. The first ACE in the ACL is intended to prevent connections to web servers in subnet 10.55.55.0/24 that do not use HTTPS. The configuration succeeds, with users that could formerly connect to those servers being denied by the ACL. The engineer then issues the show access-list command. Which answers display an output line with all the information you would expect to see in this command’s output per the scenario in this question?
explanation:
First, look to the left side of the answers. Some list line numbers, and some do not. On IOS and IOS XE, the show access-list command lists the line numbers used for each ACE in an ACL – even for ACLs defined by numbered ACL access-list global commands. By default, IOS assigns line numbers starting at 10 for increments of 10, so the first line of the ACL (represented by the answers) will use line number 10. These facts rule out two answers as incorrect.

If the ACL has been enabled on an interface, and packets have matched the ACE, the show access-list command lists a count of the number of matches for that ACE. The question states that an engineer enabled the ACL. Given that users could connect to the servers before enabling the ACL, but now they cannot, it appears that the ACL matches (and denies) those packets. As a result, the command should list a line-ending statistic about the number of packets that matched the ACE. Only one of the answers that begins with line number 10 also lists a non-zero value for that statistic, making it the correct answer.

answerChoices.Text: deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www (18 matches)
10 deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www (18 matches)
10 deny tcp any 10.55.55.0 0.0.0.255 eq www (0 matches)

questionText:
Which named ACL listed in the exhibit would adequately replace ACL 150 shown here: 

access-list 150 deny tcp host 172.16.1.128 host 10.1.2.3 eq smtp
access-list 150 deny udp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 host 10.1.2.3 eq tftp
access-list 150 deny tcp 172.16.0.0 0.0.255.255 host 10.1.2.3 eq 22
access-list 150 permit ip any any
explanation: When converting a numbered ACL to a named ACL, it first must be determined which type of ACL is being converted. In this case, because the number used is 150, it is an extended ACL. This is then used to perform the initial creation of the ACL with the ip access-list extended name command; this will enter the user into extended named ACL configuration mode. The commands from here are very similar to those used with a numbered list but without the access-list and the ACL number at the beginning of the statement. For example, access-list 150 deny udp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 host 10.1.2.3 eq tftp becomes deny udp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 host 10.1.2.3 eq tftp.

questionText: Which extended ACL port number parameter indicates a direct match for a specific application/application number?
explanation: There are five different port number parameters that can be used to perform different types of match, including eq (equal), ne (not equal), lt (less than), gt (greater than), and range.

questionText: A junior-level engineer has been given the task of configuring an ACL on a router; he was told that the port that should be blocked is TCP 20. Which access-list command keyword could be used in place of this port number when configured?
explanation:
There are a number of common application port numbers that can be configured using an access-list command keyword in place of the actual port number. TCP port number 20 is used for File Transfer Protocol data, which can be configured (as is shown in the configuration) using the keyword ftp-data. The others are:


	TFTP: UDP 69
	FTP Control: TCP 21
	SMTP: TCP 25

questionText:
Consider the following output from a show access-list command. Which ACE matches packets that use source addresses between 10.22.33.30 to 10.22.33.80, with any destination address, and destined to an SSH server application?


ip access-list extended sample
  10 permit tcp 10.22.33.0 0.0.0.63 any eq 22
  20 permit tcp 10.22.33.0 0.0.0.127 eq 22 any
  30 permit tcp 10.22.33.0 0.0.0.31 any eq 22
  40 permit tcp 10.22.33.0 0.0.0.255 any eq 22
explanation:
The question states that the output comes from a command in a router so that you can rely on the access control entries (ACEs) having correct syntax. You can also expect that for the address and wildcard pairs, the address represents the lowest number in a range, with the highest number found by adding the address and wildcard mask. For instance, 10.22.33.0 + 0.0.0.63, added octet-by-octet, gives you 10.22.33.63. The source addresses in the ACL define these ranges, all of which include the source address 10.22.33.30 in the question.


	Line 10: 10.22.33.0 – 10.22.33.63
	Line 20: 10.22.33.0 – 10.22.33.127
	Line 30: 10.22.33.0 – 10.22.33.31
	Line 40: 10.22.33.0 – 10.22.33.255


From that analysis, you can see that lines 20 and 40 emcompass the range of source addresses in the question stem, ruling out lines 10 and 30 as possible correct answers.




For ACEs 20 and 40, line 20 matches the SSH well-known port 22 as the source port, not the destination port, so its logic cannot match packets destined to an SSH server. Line 40 works because it matches the source and destination addresses per the question and also matches SSH as the destination port, port 22.

questionText: Your boss assigns you a task to create ACL ACEs for an extended IPv4 ACL. The goal is to permit all traffic from any source address destined for web servers in the new data center subnet 10.10.48.0/20. Your ACEs should match web traffic that uses all HTTP versions with the servers using default port numbers. Which answers list one of the ACEs? (Choose three answers.)
explanation:
The question asks for ACEs that support all HTTP versions. That includes:


	HTTP 1.0, 1.1, and 2.0, which use TCP and default well-known server TCP port 80 when not using Secure HTTP
	HTTP 1.0, 1.1, and 2.0, which use TCP, with the default well-known server TCP port 443 when also using TLS (Secure HTTP).
	HTTP 3.0, which uses UDP, TLS, and QUIC, and default well-known UDP port 443


Additionally, to match the addresses in subnet 10.10.48.0/20, calculate the wildcard mask based on the DDN mask. First, /20 converts to DDN mask 255.255.240.0. Subtract that value from 255.255.255.255 to find the wildcard mask:

255.255.255.255 – 255.255.240.0 = 0.0.15.255

The correct answers all match the source address with the any keyword. They match the destination address with the combined subnet ID and wildcard mask of 10.10.48.0 0.0.15.255. The three correct answers then match TCP destination port 80 (for HTTP 1.0 traffic), TCP destination port 443 (for HTTP 1.1 and 2.0 traffic with TLS), and UDP destination port 443 (for HTTP 3.0 traffic.)

questionText: As supported on a router running IOS XE, which supports the “Common” ACL feature,  which answer accurately describes the limits IOS XE places on the number of IP ACLs on one router?
explanation:
Cisco IOS has long supported one IP ACL, per interface, per direction (in or out). For example, the ip access-group acl_01 out and ip access-group acl_02 in commands can coexist on an interface because they use opposite directions. However, if at that point you also configured another command to enable an IP ACL in the same direction on that interface – for instance, using the ip access-group acl_03 out command - it would replace the ip access-group 1 out command as the only outbound IP ACL on the interface.


With the IOS XE Common ACL feature, you can configure two IP ACLs per interface per direction. The command syntax changes to ip access-group common common-acl regular-acl in|out. IOS XE processes the ACLs as if it matches the common ACL first and then the regular ACL. As a result, the long-held rule of one IP ACL per interface per direction expands to two ACLs.

answerChoices.Text: One per router interface per direction
Two per router interface per direction
Many per router interface per direction

questionText:
The text below shows a series of configuration commands in a text editor. An engineer then copies and pastes the commands into configuration mode on an IOS XE router. Afterward, she issues a show ip interface g0/0/0 command - a command whose output includes a line that begins “Incoming Common access list is…” Which answer lists the word(s) that will appear at the end of that output line?


interface g0/0/0
  ip access-group common four five in
  ip access-group 101 in
  ip access-group common one two in
  ip access-group three in

In the beginning, before adding and enabling an ACL, any user could SSH to router R1 and receive a login prompt. Later, to make R1 more secure, an engineer configures ACL QA_05 (listed below), in an attempt to allow only clients from subnet 10.1.10.0/24 to SSH to the router. The engineer enables the ACL with the access-class QA_05 in subcommand in vty mode. When a user at host 10.1.10.111 attempts to SSH to a working IP address on router R1, which ACE (per the output below) does R1 match?


ip access-list extended QA_05
  10 permit udp any 10.1.10.0 0.0.0.255
  15 permit udp 10.1.10.0 0.0.0.255 any
  20 permit tcp 10.1.10.0 0.0.0.255 any
  25 permit tcp any 10.1.10.0.0 0.0.0.255
explanation:
In this scenario, the packets have these important protocol facts:


	Protocol: IP followed by TCP
	Source addresses: Subnet 10.1.10.0/24, specifically 10.1.10.111
	Source port: dynamic (above 49,151)
	Destination address: 10.1.20.1
	Destination port: 22 (SSH well-known port)


When enabled as an inbound vty ACL as described, IOS matches only Telnet and SSH packets regardless of the port matching in the ACL. When examining the protocol and address fields, ACEs 10 and 15 refer to UDP, so those do not match the packets. ACEs 20 and 25 match based on the tcp protocol keyword. However, ACEs 20 and 25 match different addresses, with ACE 20 matching the intended source IP address range for subnet 10.1.10.0/24. (ACE 25 matches that same address range as the destination address range, which does not match the packets.) So, the packets, in this case, will match ACE 20.

answerChoices.Text: The implied deny ip any any at the end of the list

questionText: Your boss asks you to suggest new ACL ACEs to match messages flowing to any POP3 server with any source and destination address. Your research shows POP3 uses well-known port 110 when not using TLS and 995 when using TLS. Your boss wants a working solution with little clutter, so he wants a solution that uses only one new ACE in the ACL. Which answer shows the option you think your boss will like best?
explanation:
First, consider a few background facts. POP3 uses TCP. IANA reserves well-known port 110 for POP3 without TLS and port 995 when POP3 uses authentication and encryption. The Cisco pop3 ACL keyword matches port 110, but it has no keyword for POP3 with encryption.

Working through various incorrect answers:


	The answer that lists one command with the pop3 keyword fails because it does not match all POP3 traffic. It matches only POP3 without TLS.
	The answer with the list keyword fails with a syntax error because the command does not support a list keyword.
	The answer with the range 110 995 parameters has correct syntax and matches both POP3 well-known ports, but it also matches all port numbers between 110 and 995 inclusive, denying far more traffic than desired.


The remaining answer meets all functional requirements, but the correct answer uses a single command. The single command that ends with eq 110 995 uses a syntax Cisco added to IOS XE to allow up to ten port numbers to be listed after the eq keyword. As a result, the command matches packets with destination port 110 or 995.

questionText: In the figure, router R1 enables an ACL inbound on its G0/0/0 interface. Hosts A and B need to lease IP addresses from DHCP server S1. Router R1 provides the IP helper feature with the ip helper-address 172.16.2.1 subcommand on its G0/0/0 interface. Which answers list an ACE that, if part of the ACL, would match DHCP messages between the server and clients?
explanation:
The DHCP messages per this question use:


	UDP
	Source address 0.0.0.0 (client address before leasing an address)
	Destination IP address 255.255.255.255 (destination used by clients because they do not know the DHCP server’s address.)
	Destination port 67 (bootps)


In this scenario, the ACL inbound on R1’s G0/0/0 interface processes the DHCP messages before the IP helper function on R1 changes the IP addresses. As a result, at this point, the router must match the special-purpose source and destination addresses 0.0.0.0 and 255.255.255.255, respectively.

Of the two answers that use the ip protocol keyword, both attempt to match address 172.16.2.1. The DHCP messages do not use that address as the source or destination address, making those answers incorrect.

The one incorrect ACE referencing the udp protocol keyword attempts to match destination address 172.16.2.1, an address not used in the packet header. That ACE also attempts a match of the wrong destination port (bootpc instead of the correct bootps.) 

The correct answer checks the correct bootps destination port. It also examines the exact source address 0.0.0.0, the correct source address of the packets sent by the DHCP clients.

answerChoices.Text: none of the ACEs would match the packets

questionText:
An engineer types the below configuration commands into a text editor and then copies and pastes them into configuration mode on an IOS XE router. The engineer then issues a show ip interface g0/0/0 command, reading the line that begins “Incoming Common access list is…” Which answer lists the word that will appear at the end of that output line?


interface g0/0/0
  ip access-group 101 in
  ip access-group common one two in
  ip access-group three in
  ip access-group common four five in
You would like to limit telnet connection into your router to a range of IP address.  You have created the access list numbered 99, how do you apply this ACL to limit telnet connections?
explanation: The correct command to apply an ACL to VTY interfaces is access-class in VTY configuration mode.
comments:
CD-I2-7-53-001-1

 

---

 

Should be placed into Chapter 34

questionText: Router R2 configuration enables an ACL outbound on its G0/0/0 interface. The ACL intercepts packets between some DHCP clients and DHCP server 172.20.11.1 in the direction from the server towards the clients. The answers list ACEs an engineer is considering for the ACL to permit DHCP messages sent by the server. Which ACEs would permit the traffic? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
First, consider some facts about the DHCP messages in this case. They all use UDP as the transport protocol. The server uses UDP port 67, with the client using UDP port 68 instead of a dynamic (ephemeral) port. The scenario requires matching packets sent by the server, so the packets have a source port of 67 (keyword bootps for the server) and a destination port of 68 (keyword bootpc for the client.)

All the commands that show the permit command match the udp protocol keyword, which is correct. All show the same source address, matching the server's IP address. All match the same destination addresses with the any keyword. The only differences lay in the position and values of the port matching.

One correct answer matches the source port used by the server using the eq 67 parameters after the source address field but before the destination address field. The other correct answer matches the destination port, matching the port used by the client with the eq 68 parameters following the destination address field. The two incorrect answers reverse that logic.

answerChoices.Text: none of the ACEs would match the packets

questionText: An engineer needs to plan and implement ACLs to protect SSH access to the routers in the enterprise, allowing SSH from only a specific set of subnets used by network engineers. For instance, the configuration should permit SSH into routers R1 and R2 in the figure from hosts in subnet 10.1.10.0/24. Which answers suggest a plan for implementing the ACLs to achieve the goals in this question?
explanation:
Two answers mention ACLs on interfaces. For an ACL enabled on an interface, inbound ACLs can work. A router processes all incoming packets with an inbound ACL. However, a router does not process self-generated packets with any enabled outbound ACL, so outbound ACLs would not attempt to match SSH packets generated by the router. 

The access-class command in vty mode enables an ACL to filter Telnet and SSH traffic in the router. Inbound, the ACL filters incoming SSH/Telnet connections from external clients – the function described in the question. Outbound, the ACL filters traffic generated by a router CLI user who uses the telnet and ssh commands to connect out of the router CLI – which is not the function described in the question.

answerChoices.Text: Inbound ACLs on all interfaces on each router with the ip access-group interface mode command
Outbound ACLs on all interfaces on each router with the ip access-group interface mode command
Inbound vty ACLs on each router with the access-class vty mode command
Outbound vty ACLs on each router with the access-class vty mode command

questionText:
Router R1 uses the ACL below, enabled on interface G0/0/1 with the ip access-group try_to_avoid_discarding_OSPF in interface subcommand. R1 becomes an OSPF neighbor with router R2 on that interface. Repeated use of the show access-lists command on router R1 shows increasing counter values for some ACEs in the ACLs, representing the number of times each ACE was matched. Which ACE’s match count increments each time router R2 sends an OSPF Hello to R1? 


ip access-list extended try_to_avoid_discarding_OSPF
  10 permit tcp host 10.1.1.2 any eq ospf
  20 permit udp host 10.1.1.2 any eq ospf
  30 permit ospf host 224.0.0.5 any
  40 permit ospf host 10.1.1.2 any
  50 permit ip 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255
explanation:
The question lists a command that enables the ACL for inbound packets. Routers apply ACL logic to all inbound packets, even packets of overhead protocols like OSPF.

The OSPF protocol does not use UDP or TCP, so IOS ACL ACEs match OSPF messages using the ospf protocol keyword. So, lines 10 and 20 do not match OSPF messages at all.

The OSPF messages sent by router R2 will use R2's unicast address 10.1.1.2 as the source, with multicast address 224.0.0.5 as the destination. Those facts rule out line 30. However, line 40 matches those addresses, making line 40 the correct answer. OSPF messages would also match line 50's matching logic but would not match line 50 because of the first-ACE-matched logic when processing an ACL.

questionText: Router R1 has the configuration shown in the exhibit. The only users allowed to telnet into R1 sit in the subnet connected to R1's Fa0/0 interface. Which of the following configuration commands, added to R1's configuration, would allow access to R1 for only those users, while allowing packets to flow through router R1?
explanation: Applying either ACL to the Fa0/0 interface will filter packets that  would otherwise have flowed through the router, which is against the  goals suggested in the question statement. The access-class in command filters telnet requests into the router, while the access-class out command filters telnet requests made from a user at the router's CLI. So, in this case, the in  option is required. Finally, ACL 1 matches only the hosts in the local  LAN - 10.1.1.0/25 (255.255.255.128). The correct ACL wildcard mask can  be found by subtracting 255.255.255.128 from 255.255.255.255, leaving  0.0.0.127.
comments:
CD-I2-7-53-002-2

--

This should be in Chapter 34

answerChoices.Text: access-class 1 in, from inside vty configuration mode
access-class 9 in, from inside vty configuration mode
access-class 9 out, from inside vty configuration mode
ip access-group 1 in, from inside interface configuration mode for Fast Ethernet 0/0
ip access-group 9 in, from inside interface configuration mode for Fast Ethernet 0/0

questionText:
Router R1 in the figure uses the configuration shown here, with the ip access-group QA_02 out interface subcommand added interface G0/0/1. The router has no other ACL-related configuration. In the show access-lists command output, which ACEs’ counters should increment each time router R1 sends an OSPF Hello?


ip access-list extended QA_02
  10 permit tcp host 172.16.12.1 any eq 520  
  20 permit tcp host 172.16.12.1 any 
  30 permit ospf host 224.0.0.5 any
  40 permit ospf host 172.16.12.1 any
explanation: The scenario for this question enables an outbound ACL on router R1 and asks which ACE would match the OSPF packets generated by R1 and sent out that interface. IOS (and IOS XE) do not attempt to match an outbound ACL for packets generated by the router, so none of the ACEs match the OSPF Hellos sent by router R1.

answerChoices.Text: none of the ACEs would match the packets

questionText: From the following spoofing attacks, which option(s) leverages an application, device, or service to increase the amount of traffic being sent toward a target?
explanation:
In a reflection attack, the attacker sends packets with a spoofed source address toward a live host, but the host is not the intended target. The attacker’s goal is to get the host in question to send traffic to the spoofed address that is the actual target.

	Another similar attack is called an amplification attack, which is a reflection attack that can leverage an application or device to increase the amount of traffic being sent toward a target, even when the attacker is originally sending a small amount of data.

	In a man-in-the-middle attack, an attacker is able to get in the direct path of two or more devices sending traffic. Once in position, the attacker can relay requests and responses back and forth, completing the traffic patterns. The attacker can modify the requests and responses it receives to its own goals while still being hidden from detection.

	A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack’s goal is to reduce a system, service, application, device, or resource to the point that it can no longer function. In most cases the target is forced to complete an unplanned shutdown to mitigate the attack.

questionText: From the malware types listed, which option(s) is packaged inside other software?
explanation:
A Trojan horse is a type of malicious application that is wrapped inside another application, which hides the Trojan horse from detection. If a user decides to install the safe wrapper application, the Trojan horse is also installed but without the end user’s knowledge. Once installed, the Trojan horse can compromise a system or exfiltrate data. A Trojan horse cannot spread from device to device or application to application without user interaction.

	A virus is a type of malicious application that can move from device to device relatively easily. The difference here is that a virus would need to properly infect another application, and then that application would need to be moved by an end user to another device.

	One of the most sophisticated types of malware, called a worm, can actually self-replicate itself and constantly spread on its own. This makes a worm one of the hardest types of malware to mitigate properly.

questionText: From the malware types listed below, which option(s) is self-injected into other software?
explanation:
A virus is a type of malicious application that can move from device to device relatively easily. The difference here is that a virus would need to properly infect another application, and then that application would need to be moved by an end user to another device.

	A Trojan horse is a type of malicious application that is wrapped inside another application, which hides the Trojan horse from detection. If a user decides to install the safe wrapper application, the Trojan horse is also installed but without the end user’s knowledge. Once installed, the Trojan horse can compromise a system or exfiltrate data. A Trojan horse cannot spread from device to device or application to application without user interaction.

	One of the most sophisticated types of malware, called a worm, can actually self-replicate itself and constantly spread on its own. This makes a worm one of the hardest types of malware to mitigate properly.

questionText: Match the attack type on the left with the goal of the attack on the right.
explanation:
There are a number of human security vulnerabilities:


	Social engineering is an attack that exploits human trust and social behavior.
	Phishing is a malicious invitation disguised as something legitimate.
	Spear phishing targets one or more specific individuals for a phishing attack.
	Whaling is an attack that targets a high-profile individual, such as a CEO or CIO of a company.
	Vishing is an attack that uses voice calls.
	Smishing is an attack that uses text (SMS) messages.
	Pharming uses legitimate services to send users to a compromised site.
	A watering hole identifies users and then attracts them to a compromised site.

questionText: Which of the following spoofing attacks eavesdrops on traffic?
explanation:
In a man-in-the-middle attack, an attacker is able to get in the direct path of two or more devices sending traffic. Once in position, the attacker can relay requests and responses back and forth, completing the traffic patterns. The attacker can modify the requests and responses it receives to its own goals while still being hidden from detection.

	A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack’s goal is to reduce a system, service, application, device, or resource to the point that it can no longer function. In most cases the target is forced to complete an unplanned shutdown to mitigate the attack.

	In a reflection attack, the attacker sends packets with a spoofed source address toward a live host, but the host is not the intended target. The attacker’s goal is to get the host in question to send traffic to the spoofed address that is the actual target.

	Another similar attack is called an amplification attack, which is a reflection attack that can leverage an application or device to increase the amount of traffic being sent toward a target, even when the attacker is originally sending a small amount of data.

questionText: Which options are true about TACACS+?
explanation: When contrasting Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) with Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus (TACACS+), there are a number of differences. RADIUS uses UDP port 1812, doesn’t encrypt the entire packet, and doesn’t support the function to authorize each user to a subset of CLI commands. TACACS+ uses TCP port 49, encrypts the entire packet, supports the function to authorize each user to a subset of CLI commands, and was developed by Cisco (but is widely supported).

questionText: From the spoofing attacks listed, which option(s) attempts to exhaust a system service or resource with the intent to crash the target system?
explanation:
A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack’s goal is to reduce a system, service, application, device, or resource to the point that it can no longer function. In most cases the target is forced to complete an unplanned shutdown to mitigate the attack.

	DDoS attacks can sometimes be used to bury nefarious activities in an avalanche of logs, making it much more difficult to find the true target of the attack.

	In a man-in-the-middle attack, an attacker is able to get in the direct path of two or more devices sending traffic. Once in position the attacker can relay requests and responses back and forth, completing the traffic patterns. The attacker can modify the requests and responses it receives to its own goals while still being hidden from detection.

	In a reflection attack, the attacker sends packets with a spoofed source address toward a live host, but the host is not the intended target. The attacker’s goal is to get the host in question to send traffic to the spoofed address that is the actual target.

	Another similar attack is called an amplification attack, which is a reflection attack that can leverage an application or device to increase the amount of traffic being sent toward a target, even when the attacker is originally sending a small amount of data.

questionText: Which AAA protocols are typically used on Cisco devices to communicate to a remote server for local device authentication?
explanation: There are two protocols that are typically used on Cisco devices for local device authentication (along with other functions): Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) and Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus (TACACS+).

questionText: Compare the authentication methods listed in the answers. Which of the listed authentication methods will typically require you use some fact that you know?
explanation:
A password is something you know that others shouldn’t know. It’s a value that you use with a username to get into a system, application, or device. A password should never be written down.

	Digital certificates use something the user has (the certificate) rather than something the user knows. The certificate is trusted by a certificate authority (CA) and approved for authentication by the administrator. Each digital certificate maintains validity with the CA chain and its specific identity-based attributes for the user account in question. Each approved digital certificate is approved for a specific account only. 

	Biometric scanners use something inherent to the user (fingerprint, eyescan, facial imprint, and so on), and has been termed “something you are.” These devices use “something you are” (eye, finger, voice, face, etc.) to help strengthen the security of your account. These body elements that identify you as you are not easily stolen or copied.

	The term two-factor authentication refers to authentication methods that use more than one other method. Two factor methods often use something you know, such as a password, and something you have, such as a time-limited token value. Utilizing both of these types of authentication factors together increases the security of your account.

questionText: Which answers are accurate of RADIUS? (Choose two answers.)
explanation: RADIUS uses UDP. Over its history, it originally used port 1645 for authentication, but later RFCs changed to call for well-known port 1645 instead. RFC 2865 defines the RADIUS protocol and the use of port 1812. Finally, comparing RADIUS and TACACS+, RADIUS has become more popular as a protocol for authenticating end users. TACACS+ has some authorization features that work well with networking devices, making it more popular for network device authentication.

answerChoices.Text: Normally uses ports 1645 or 1812 for authentication
Preferred over TACACS+ for end-user authentication

questionText: From the password authentication and alternatives listed below, which option(s) includes something you are?
explanation:
Biometric scanners add another level of security to the mix, which has been termed “something you are.” These devices use “something you are” (eye, finger, voice, face, etc.) to help strengthen the security of your account. These body elements that identify you as you are not easily stolen or copied.

	Two-factor authentication includes something you know, such as a password, and something you have, such as a time-limited token value. Utilizing both of these types of authentication factors together increases the security of your account.

	Digital certificates are another factor for authentication in which they are a trusted by a certificate authority (CA) and approved for authentication by the administrator. Each digital certificate maintains validity with the CA chain and its specific identity-based attributes for the user account in question. Each approved digital certificate is approved for a specific account only. A digital certificate is also something you have.

	A password is something you know that others shouldn’t know. It’s a value that you use with a username to get into a system, application, or device. A password should never be written down.

questionText: Match the AAA terms to their respective definitions.
Which protocol is being utilized in this figure?
explanation:
RADIUS is a standards-based client/server protocol that merges the authentication and authorization functionality into a single resource. RADIUS communicates over UDP ports 1812 and 1813. It is not completely encrypted or secure.

TACACS+ is a client/server protocol that separates the Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting functionality. TACACS+ utilizes TCP port 49 and its traffic is encrypted. TACACS+ is a Cisco proprietary protocol and its communication is secure.

The Domain Name System (DNS) protocol is used to resolve IP addresses to hostnames and hostnames to IP addresses. Its communication is not encrypted or secure by default. DNS utilizes both UDP and TCP in different instances. DNS uses port 53 for both TCP and UDP. DNS does not support AAA.

HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is used to browse the Internet. Specifically, you utilize uniform resource locators (URL) to locate a web address on the Internet or local network.

questionText: Your organization requires all traffic to be encrypted and communications to be secure. From the different protocols listed, which protocol meets these requirements and supports AAA?
explanation:
TACACS+ is a client/server protocol that separates the Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting functionality. TACACS+ utilizes TCP port 49, and its traffic is encrypted. TACACS+ is a Cisco proprietary protocol and its communication is secure.

The Domain Name System (DNS) protocol is used to resolve IP addresses to hostnames and hostnames to IP addresses. Its communication is not encrypted or secure by default. DNS utilizes both UDP and TCP in different instances. DNS uses port 53 for both TCP and UDP and does not support AAA.

RADIUS is a standards-based client/server protocol that merges the authentication and authorization functionality into a single resource. RADIUS communicates over UDP ports 1812 and 1813. It is not completely encrypted or secure.

HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is used to browse the Internet. Specifically, you utilize uniform resource locators (URL) to locate a web address on the Internet or a local network. Although today most use of HTTP also uses TLS to secure the protocol, HTTP itself does not secure the traffic.

questionText: Which answer best describes how RADIUS and TACACS+ encrypt passwords and data?
explanation: Both protocols encrypt authentication flows, protecting the passwords used to authenticate the user. However, Radius does not encrypt the data sent between the devices once authentication is complete, while TACACS+ encrypts all data.

answerChoices.Text: Both encrypt both authentication passwords and all data
Neither encrypt both authentication passwords and all data
Only Radius but not TACACS+ encrypts both authentication passwords and all data
Only TACACS+ but not Radius encrypts both authentication passwords and all data

questionText: From the password authentication and alternatives listed below, which option(s) includes something you have?
explanation:
Two-factor authentication includes something you know, such as a password, and something you have, such as a time-limited token value. Utilizing both of these types of authentication factors together increases the security of your account.

	Digital certificates are another factor for authentication in which they are trusted by a certificate authority (CA) and approved for authentication by the administrator. Each digital certificate maintains validity with the CA chain and its specific identity-based attributes for the user account in question. Each approved digital certificate is approved for a specific account only. A digital certificate is also something you have.

	Biometric scanners add another level of security to the mix, which has been termed “something you are.” These devices use “something you are” (eye, finger, voice, face, etc.) to help strengthen the security of your account. These body elements that identify you as you are not easily stolen or copied.

	A password is something you know that others shouldn’t know. It is a value that you use with a username to get into a system, application, or device. A password should never be written down.

questionText: Which options are true about the RADIUS?
explanation: When contrasting Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) with Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus (TACACS+), there are a number of differences. RADIUS uses UDP port 1812, doesn’t encrypt the entire packet, and doesn’t support the function to authorize each user to a subset of CLI commands. TACACS+ uses TCP port 49, encrypts the entire packet, supports the function to authorize each user to a subset of CLI commands, and was developed by Cisco (but is widely supported).

questionText: In what security zone are the public web servers located?
explanation:
The DMZ zone is where your hosted services, such as a public-facing web server, would live. It’s in your network still but in another security zone, with additional security controls to protect the inside zone but also allow outside users access to the service.

	An inside zone is where user traffic toward the Internet is initiated. This traffic is usually allowed outbound. This is not the location where you should put your public-facing web servers.

	The outside zone is where the Internet is located. Traffic that was initiated by the user from the inside zone is traditionally allowed back through the outside zone. Unless the firewall specifically allows the communication through with a rule or policy, initiated traffic from the outsize zone is blocked.

	You can create any naming scheme for your security zones, but campus is not a traditional zone name and is not where you should put your public-facing web servers.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command would be used to configure a username and password that would be stored using MD5 in a router running IOS?
explanation:
Just as there are two different ways to configure the enable password (enable password or enable secret), there are also two different ways to configure a username on a Cisco IOS device: using the username username password password command (which stores the password in clear text or with limited security) or using the username username secret password command (which by default stores the password as an MD5 hash). 

Note that Cisco IOS routers default to store hashed passwords using MD5, but Cisco IOS XE routers default to use the scrypt hash algorithm instead.

questionText: The show running-config command output on a router includes the following line: username test05 secret 8 $8$rTJqzmkwdI20WU$.mktApC8shjjwgABbQp7UjOmttmJaiIDfvBBJOpcns6. Which answer best describes the command the network engineer used to originally configure this username command with its clear-text password?
explanation: The username secret command in the question stem shows a type of 8. Type 8 refers to the SHA256 hash type, configured with the algorithm-type sha256 parameters.  The other incorrect answers mention type 9 (Scrypt) and type 5 (MD5). Also, the answer with username test05 secret cisco, omitting the algorithm-type keyword, differs basd on the OS. IOS defaults to use MD5 and IOS XE defaults to use Scrypt. However, neither default would result in the output listed in the question, making that answer incorrect no matter which of the two router operating systems were in use.

questionText: IPS signatures look for what type of attack(s)?
explanation: IPS signatures look for all of these types of attacks: DoS, DDoS, worms, and viruses.

questionText: What is the name of the firewall feature that, when used, can maintain a historical database of each connection through a device: where it was sourced, destined, and which protocol and protocol port it was using?
explanation: One of the most common features on almost all firewalls (from cheap to expensive) is the support for Stateful inspection. A Stateful inspection engine allows a firewall to track and maintain a database of the connections coming into and, if allowed, out of a port. This information can then be used to determine which traffic should be permitted and which should not.

questionText: Which hashing algorithm has been utilized in this figure for the cisco user account?
explanation: The username name secret password command can use keywords algorithm-type md5, algorithm-type sha256, and algorithm-type scrypt. When stored in the running config file, IOS replaces those keywords with a number: 5, 8, and 9, respectively. For this question, the output shows an "8", meaning the command uses keywords algorithm-type sha256, which internally using the SHA256 algorithm.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; assuming common firewall zone configuration, which packet initiation paths would not be allowed?
explanation: Typical firewall zone configuration would serve to protect the inside of the network from potential attackers that exist on the open Internet. Because of this, it is common for firewall zones to be established; typically, these include an inside, outside, and DMZ zone. The inside zone is typically allowed to initiate traffic to both other zones; the outside zone is typically limited to only initiating connections to the DMZ; and the DMZ zone sits in an intermediate position and may be allowed to initiate some communications into the inside zone on a case-by-case basis to ensure security.

questionText: Which hashing algorithm has been utilized in this figure for the enable secret password?
comments: 7/29 - correct as-is, The question asked the algorithm used, not which config parameter was used, making SHA-256 correct., 7/20 - query to Au, 5/12 - question good as-is  "I think I can predict why you thought “scrypt” is correct. The question asks about the hashing algorithm, not the keyword in the configuration command. I agree, type 9 is configured with the “scrypt” keyword, as also noted in the explanation to the question. Both type 8 and 9 use SHA-256 as the encryption algorithm, which is the fact assessed by the question.  5/9 - query to Au

questionText: When comparing next-generation IPS to traditional IPS, what additional capability(ies) can be leveraged to more efficiently block traffic?
explanation:
With an NGIPS you get the additional capabilities of application visibility and control (AVC), contextual awareness, and event impact level. Each of these capabilities makes it easier and more efficient to block malicious traffic.

	Both a traditional IPS as well as an NGIPS will filter based on a signature database downloaded by the IPS, so it is not a difference between the older IPS and newer NGIPS.

questionText: Which security function would be the best option to recognize a DoS attack?
explanation:
A stateful firewall has the capability to track historical information about traffic that has passed through it, to then make semi-intelligent decisions based on that historical information. With these capabilities, a stateful firewall is properly enabled to mitigate a DoS attack. For instance, if can monitor the number of TCP connections to each IP address over time, watching for volumes that seem out-of-range versus normal operation.

	A stateless firewall and router ACL do not have the mechanisms or capabilities to provide any sort of historical information about the traffic that has passed through the security function. While they can match individual packets, they cannot consider past packets and trends that can identify a DoS attack.

	A security zone is a security component of a firewall where a designation is determined. Normally there is an inside and outside security zone, and traffic can be segmented between these zones one way or another. For example, traffic initiated from the inside security zone can traverse through the outside security zone, but traffic initiated from the outside security zone cannot traverse the inside security zone without proper approval. A security zone does not mitigate a DoS attack.

questionText: Which hash method does a router running Cisco IOS use by deault when configuring the enable secret command?
explanation: By default, Cisco IOS uses the Message Digest-5 (MD5) algorithm to store passwords entered with the enable secret (and username secret) commands. Other options are becoming available with new releases of IOS but have not taken over the default role. Router running IOS XE default to one of the newer alternatives (scrypt.)

questionText:
You have configured the following on your Catalyst switch:

SW1(config-if)# interface G0/1
SW1(config-if)# switchport mode access
SW1(config-if)# switchport port-security maximum 5
SW1(config-if)# switchport port-security mac-address sticky
SW1(config-if)# do show port-security
Secure Port  MaxSecureAddr  CurrentAddr  SecurityViolation Security  Action
                (Count)        (Count)          (Count)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total Addresses in System (excluding one mac per port)     : 0
Max Addresses limit in System (excluding one mac per port) : 6144

	You expected to see port g0/1 as a secure port in the output of the do show port-security command. Why is port g0/1 not listed as a secure port?
explanation: Port security’s default can be modified but will not actually begin to work until we use the command switchport port-security in interface configuration mode to enable it, and that is why it is not showing in the output.As for the wrong answers, the switch port defaults to VLAN 1 unless otherwise configured. Port-security features that are part of a licensed IOS image on the switch do not require an additional separate license to operate. The port must be configured as an access port to support port security.

answerChoices.Text: You forgot to enable port security.
It will not show up unless the MAC addresses exceeds five for that port.
The switch port is not assigned to a VLAN.
Port security, if configured, requires an additional license to work.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; you have been tasked to help implement security measures for your company, which is going to place a number of public access computer terminals in its retail locations. Part of this process is securing the Ethernet ports that will be used by these terminals; this will be done by implementing Cisco’s port security feature on SW2 and SW3. Your boss wants to make sure that the ports are forced into a disabled state if another device is plugged into them. In this case, which port security violation mode should be configured on these ports?
explanation: There are three different port security violation modes: shutdown, restrict, and protect. The shutdown mode will disable a port if a device with an unauthorized MAC address attempts to send traffic. The restrict mode will ignore any traffic from unauthorized MAC addresses, log the violation, and send a message to the SNMP manager (if it is configured), but it will NOT disable the port. The protect mode will ignore any traffic from unauthorized MAC addresses, but it will not log the violation or send a message to the SNMP manager or disable the port.

questionText: What command should you configure globally to enable automatic recovery of port security errdisable states?
explanation: This question is testing your understanding of what command to configure to enable automatic recovery of port security errdisable states. Three of the four options are not valid commands but look similar to the correct command. The correct command is errdisable recovery cause psecure-violation.

questionText: After enabling port security in restrict mode on an interface, which Cisco IOS command could be used to show the number of discarded frames (if any) as well as the last source MAC address?
explanation: Both the show port-security and show port-security interface interface commands can be used to display the port security violation counters of an interface. When the interface configuration enables the restrict violation mode, the show port-security interface interface command displays (a) the total number of discarded frames and (b) the last source MAC address seen on an interface. This command can be helpful in troubleshooting which device is sending the frames that are being dropped. The show interface switchport command does not show information about port security, and show switchport security is not a valid Cisco IOS command.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command would be used to display the current violation mode for all configured Port Security interfaces?
explanation: Both the show port-security and show port-security interface interface commands can be used to display the port security violation mode of an interface; only the former will show it for all configured port security interfaces.

questionText: The status of a LAN switch interface shows err-disabled. Which of the following would have caused this status?
explanation:
If port security is configured on a switch port, and there is a violation of those port security parameters (such as more than the allowed number of source MAC addresses), the default behavior is to place the port into an err-disable state.

In addition, the question is inferring that the EtherChannel should be configured as a trunk and not as an access link; a simple switchport mode trunk solves this.

questionText: The exhibit shows the configuration on switch SW2. The switch has just been reloaded, and no end-user traffic has flowed into the switch yet. Assuming that the details in the figure are correct, which of the following statements are true about port security on SW2? Note that all ports are in default VLAN 1.
explanation: SW2's Fa0/3 uses the protect violation mode, with a default to allow a single MAC address in this case, 0200.1111.1111. So, SW2 discards frames with source MAC address 0200.3333.3333 that enter Fa0/3, but it doesn't send SNMP traps, and it doesn't error-disable the interface. As a result, frames can be sent out Fa0/3, including the broadcast sent by PC2. When PC4 sends a frame to PC3, the first frame since reload that enters Fa0/4, SW2 adds PC4's MAC address to the port security configuration, as a result of the sticky keyword in the original configuration. SW2 forwards the frame out Fa0/3, because it is not error-disabled at all in this example, allowing PC3 to send a frame to PC4 in reply. But SW2 silently discards the frame from PC3 (0200.3333.3333) because of the port security protect option.

answerChoices.Text: If the first two frames sent into the switch are 1) a frame from PC4 to  PC3's MAC address and 2) a frame sent by PC3 to PC4's MAC address,  SW2 places Fa0/4 in an error disabled (err-disabled) state.
When PC3 sends frames, SW2 disables its Fa0/3 interface.

If the first two frames sent into the switch are 1) a frame from PC4 to PC3's MAC address and 2) a frame sent by PC3 to PC4's MAC address, SW2's configuration now includes a switchport port-security mac-address sticky 0200.4444.4444 subcommand.
After both PC3 and PC4 have sent at least one frame, PC2 sends a broadcast, which SW2 forwards out both Fa0/3 and Fa0/4.

The final configuration item you need is how the switchport is going to act when the three-client threshold has been tripped. The question is asking for you to configure the switchport to log the infringement and allow the port to stay active. To accomplish this step, utilize the command switchport port-security violation restrict. With all of these commands you are left with option C as the correct answer.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; you have been tasked to help implement security measures for your company, which is going to place a number of public access computer terminals in its retail locations. Part of this process is securing the Ethernet ports that will be used by these terminals; this will be done by implementing Cisco’s port security feature on SW2 and SW3. Your boss wants to make sure that any traffic from unauthorized devices is logged but not affect the operation of the terminals. In this case, which port security violation mode should be configured on these ports?
explanation: There are three different port security violation modes: shutdown, restrict, and protect. The shutdown mode will disable a port if a device with an unauthorized MAC address attempts to send traffic. The restrict mode will ignore any traffic from unauthorized MAC addresses, log the violation, and send a message to the SNMP manager (if it is configured), but it will NOT disable the port. The protect mode will ignore any traffic from unauthorized MAC addresses, but it will not log the violation or send a message to the SNMP manager or disable the port.

questionText: What command would need to be utilized to allow DAI to check for IP addresses?
explanation: There is only one validate command as an option, ip arp inspection validate ip. This command has the following options ip arp inspection validate {[dst-mac] [src-mac] [ip]}.

questionText: What commands would you need to configure to enable DHCP Snooping so that PC4 can never become a rogue DHCP server within this network?
explanation:
To meet the requirements here, you need to enable DHCP Snooping globally and for the specific VLAN PC4 is on (VLAN 20), on SW2. You accomplish this with these commands: ip dhcp snooping and ip dhcp snooping vlan 20 on SW2. The ports all use a default setting of untrusted for DHCP Snooping, meaning that DHCP Snooping will prevent PC4 from becoming a DHCP server.

	Additionally, to support normal DHCP operations, you need to change some ports to be trusted so that SW2 will not filter DHCP messages originally sent by the legitimate DHCP server. The server connectes to SW2's Gi0/12 port, also in VLAN 20. To allow those server messages, SW2 also needs an ip dhcp snooping trust command on SW2's port Gi0/12, which connects to the DHCP server.

explanation:

Now because you are still on SW1, you need to ensure that you trust the trunk link between SW1 and SW2. You accomplish this with the command ip dhcp snooping trust on interface Gi0/24.

questionText: If there is an environment that has a DHCP server and the network device isn’t acting as a DHCP relay agent, what command would you want to include in your deployment to ensure DHCP Snooping functions properly?
explanation: DHCP Snooping uses normal default settings that work in networks that leverage a switch that acts as both a Layer 3 switch and a DHCP relay agent. The DHCP messages are actually modified to handle these additional features, which are documented in RFC 3046. If the switch does not also act as a DHCP relay agent, DHCP can stop working for end users. To mitigate this, you must disable these additional extensions, option 82, to DHCP Snooping. You accomplish this with the global command no ip dhcp snooping information option.

explanation:
This figure shows the process and workflow for Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI). Specifically, it is showing how DAI compares the incoming ARP message from PC2 with the DHCP Snooping binding table on SW1. In this example, there is no match, so the ARP message is discarded.

	Although the DHCP Snooping binding table is shown in this figure, it is not specifically focusing on what DHCP Snooping does as a feature.

	Gratuitous ARP is a process where a host would send out an ARP message to everyone on the subnet stating that this host has an updated MAC address. This figure does not show this process.

	This figure does not show a normal ARP Reply, as the message sent by PC2 lists PC1's IP address.

questionText: Referencing the figure, what feature should be implemented on SW1 to mitigate the fake DHCP server?
explanation:
To mitigate the fake DHCP server, DHCP Snooping should be enabled on SW1, trusting Gi0/24 and untrusting the rest of the ports on SW1. This will ensure that if a client computer such as PC2 were to stand up a DHCP server, the corresponding DHCP messages would be discarded as they entered SW2’s Gi/02 switchport.

	Dynamic ARP inspection (DAI) is a feature that validates MAC and IP address matching with the DHCP Snooping table to ensure that what is being received is a validate IP address, MAC address, and port listing.

	ARP Spoofing is a type of attack that sends a false MAC address instead of the client’s own MAC address.

	VLAN Snooping is not a real feature.

questionText: What does DAI look for to help validate correct ARP entries?
explanation:
Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) looks at both the DHCP Snooping binding data and ARP ACLs to help validate correct ARP entries.

	DAI does not check in the ARP table directly to validate correct ARP entries, but it can be configured to complete other checks.

	Infrastructure ACLs are not related to DAI. Infrastructure ACLs are traditionally applied to Switch VLAN Interfaces (SVI) to secure traffic.

questionText: Match the feature terms with their correct definitions.
explanation:
Gratuitous ARP informs all hosts on a subnet about its current MAC addresses. This is a normal process when a device has recently changed its MAC address and needs to inform the rest of the subnet. Attackers like to take advantage of this feature for malicious intent.

	DHCP Snooping can be utilized to mitigate a rouge DHCP server providing address leases to end devices.

	Dynamic ARP Inspection is used to validate ARP information as it’s coming into the device. This information is validated with the DHCP Snooping binding data and the ARP ACLs if configured.

	DHCP Server is a system that provides IP addresses dynamically to end devices.

questionText: Which DHCP messages are blocked by the DHCP snooping feature when a switch port is configured as untrusted?
explanation: There are four different messages that are used by the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP): Discover, Offer, Request, and Acknowledgement. The Discover and Request messages are sent from the host to the DHCP server, while the Offer and Acknowledgements are sent from the server to the hosts; it is these messages that are blocked from switch ports that are configured as untrusted.

questionText: What are the DHCP Snooping rules?
explanation:
The following are the common rules for DHCP Snooping:

	
		DHCP messages received on an untrusted port, for messages normally sent by a server, will always be discarded.
	
		DHCP messages received on an untrusted port, as normally sent by a DHCP client, may be filtered if they appear to be part of an attack.
	
		DHCP messages received on a trusted port will be forwarded; trusted ports do not filter any DHCP messages.

answerChoices.Text: DHCP messages received on an untrusted port, for messages normally sent by a server, will always be forwarded.
DHCP messages received on an untrusted port, for messages normally sent by a server, will always be discarded.
DHCP messages received on an untrusted port, as normally sent by a DHCP client, may be filtered if they appear to be part of an attack.
DHCP messages received on an untrusted port, as normally sent by a DHCP client, will be discarded.
DHCP messages received on a trusted port will be forwarded; trusted ports do not filter any DHCP messages.
DHCP messages received on a trusted port will be discarded.

questionText: What are the different DHCP Snooping port states?
explanation:
There are two DHCP Snooping port states on a switch, untrusted and trusted. The majority of the switchports will be configured as untrusted while only uplink ports toward a DHCP server and the direct DHCP server ports should be configured as Trusted.

	Outside and Inside are not related to DHCP Snooping.

	LAN and WAN are not related to DHCP Snooping.

You accomplish this with these commands: ip dhcp snooping, ip dhcp snooping vlan 10, and ip dhcp snooping vlan 20 on both switches. Next, you need to trust the DHCP server uplink port on SW2 with ip dhcp snooping trust in port interface Gi0/12. Finally, you need to trust to the trunk link between SW1 and SW2 from SW1’s side of the connection so that DHCP messages sent by the server, arriving back at switch SW1, will not be filtered. You do this with the same command, ip dhcp snooping trust, but on SW1’s interface Gi0/24 interface.

questionText: You’ve implemented DAI on a Layer 2 switch in your network, and now you want to monitor the ARP message rates with an average of two received ARP messages a second. Which command(s) would need to be utilized to accomplish this?
explanation:
All the options have the correct command syntax, so it’s a matter of which options have the correct average received ARP messages a second. There are three correct answers. First is 10 messages with an interval of 5 seonds, which ends up being two ARP messages a second. Second is 4 messages with an interval of 2 seconds, which also ends up being two ARP messages a second. Finally, 2 messages but there is no interval provided so utilize the default interval of 1 second, which gives you two ARP messages a second.

	The other two options give an average of four ARP messages a second.

questionText:
The text below lists five log messages per the output of the show logging command on a router. Which logging message level did IOS assign to the message about OSPF Hellos?


-	%LINK-5-CHANGED: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to administratively down
-	%LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN: Line protocol on Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to down
-	%SYS-5-CONFIG_I: Configured from console by console
-	%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to up 
-	OSPF-1 HELLO Gi0/1: Send hello to 224.0.0.5 area 0 from 172.16.1.1
explanation:
Cisco IOS logging defines eight message severity levels, each with a name and a matching numeric value (0-7). The following table lists the values:


	0-Emergency
	1-Alert
	2-Critical
	3-Error
	4-Warning
	5-Informational
	6-Notification
	7-Debug


IOS lists the log message level number in the codes in the front of most messages. The severity level resides within BOLD text that begins with a %. However, IOS does not typically list the message level for debug messages. Debug messages may use uppercase text, but do not begin with a %. So, the message with the text "OSPF-1" near the beginning of the message is level 7 or debug message level.

questionText: What would happen if R1 loses the two configured reference clocks?
explanation: When a device is configured for both NTP servers and NTP master, the device will synchronize time with the best-known time source based on the stratum levels. The configured NTP servers in this question would have a lower (better) stratum level than the configured ntp master 4 command. If all NTP servers were reachable, R1 would synchronize time with them over the internal clock. Because the connectivity to the two NTP servers is obstructed, R1 utilizes its local internal clock to synchronize time and to continue to provide time to the network.

answerChoices.Text: R1 would no longer be used as an NTP server
R1 would use a public Internet NTP server
R1 would use a local NTP server
R1 would use its local internal clock

questionText:

-	%LINK-5-CHANGED: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to administratively down
-	%LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN: Line protocol on Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to down
-	%SYS-5-CONFIG_I: Configured from console by console
-	%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to up 
-	OSPF-1 HELLO Gi0/1: Send hello to 224.0.0.5 area 0 from 172.16.1.1
explanation:
Cisco IOS logging defines eight message severity levels, each with a name and a matching numeric value (0-7). The following table lists the values:


	0-Emergency
	1-Alert
	2-Critical
	3-Error
	4-Warning
	5-Notification
	6-Informational
	7-Debug


The question suggests that configuring the shutdown interface subcommand generated one of the log messages. Using that command on an interface moves the interface to an administratively down state, as noted in the first log message.

The log messages embed the logging message level in the initial text code. The first log message in the list, generated due to the shutdown interface subcommand, begins with “%LINK-5-CHANGED:” identifying the message level as level 5 or notification.

questionText: Refer to the diagram. An engineer is tasked with configuring NTP on the devices displayed. R1 is intended to be the primary time source for R2, and R2 is the primary time source for R3. Which Cisco IOS command would be required to configure R1 into this role using a stratum level of 2?
explanation: A few different commands are typically used to configure basic NTP; they include the ntp server, ntp peer, and the ntp master commands. The ntp server command indicates that a device intends to get its time from the configured server but is unwilling to give it to that server (it can, however, give time to other devices, as long as its primary source is active). The ntp peer command indicates that a device intends to get its time from the configured peer and is willing to give its time to that peer should that peer lose its primary clock source (this is usually configured as a backup configuration). The ntp master command configures a device as an authoritative clock source. This command is usually used along with the ntp server command on core devices to ensure that if the core device loses its primary clock source (as configured with the ntp server command), it can still offer an authoritative clock source to other devices that use it as their primary clock source. In this scenario, R1 would need to be configured with the ntp master 2 command to allow other devices to use it as their time source.

questionText: The configuration of a router uses default settings related to terminal monitor, and none of the users have changed their settings after login. User 1 connects to the console, user 2 connects via Telnet, and user 3 connects via SSH. User 3 issues debug ip ospf hello. Which user(s) sees the debug messages?
explanation:
By default, all log messages are shown to console users for all severity levels of messages, so User 1 would be the only one seeing the log messages for the issued debug command.

	For the other users and sessions (Telnet and SSH), two commands must be issued to see these same debug messages while logged in to. The first command is logging monitor, which is a global command, and the second is terminal monitor, which is a global command that is session based, meaning that it must be configured during the current logged-in session.

questionText: Refer to the diagram. An engineer is tasked with configuring NTP on the devices displayed. R1 is intended to be the primary time source for R2, and R2 as being the primary time source for R3. Which Cisco IOS command would be required to configure R2 to use R1 as its primary clock source?
explanation:
A few different commands are typically used to configure basic NTP; they include the ntp server, ntp peer, and the ntp master commands. Specifically:

	The ntp server command defines the IP address of some other NTP server, so that the local device synchronizes its time based on that NTP server's time. Also, a device configured with the ntp server command can act as an NTP server for other devices as well, as long as the device also has some other primary clock source (for instance, as configured with the ntp master command). 

	The ntp peer command indicates that a device intends to both synchronize its time with the configured peer, and to supply time information back to that peer.

	The ntp master command configures a device as an authoritative clock source. This command is usually used along with the ntp server command on core devices to ensure that if the core device loses its primary clock source (as configured with the ntp server command), it can still offer an authoritative clock source to other devices that use it as their primary clock source.

	In this scenario, R2 would need to use the ntp server 10.10.10.1 command to use R1 as its primary clock source.

questionText: An engineer needs to plan the configuration for layer 3 switch D1. It has all default CDP configuration so far. The goal: disable CDP on the upper link (G1/0/1) and enable it for all others. The engineer creates four solutions they can copy/paste into global configuration mode. Which answer achieves the CDP configuration goal and will not result in any IOS messages about invalid commands?
explanation:
In this specific case, you can achieve the stated goal by enabling CDP by default so that any interface with a subcommand to change the setting will use CDP. Then, you combine that with the interface subcommand that disables CDP on that specific interface, overriding the default. In summary, the question asks to enable CDP on all interfaces but to override that setting for interface G1/0/1.

CDP and LLDP use the same conventions with the run and enable keywords in the commands to enable/disable the protocols. Cisco chose the run keyword for the global commands and enable for the interface subcommands. As a result, the correct config is:


cdp run                      ! Global command, default CDP on
interface GigabitEthernet 1/0/1
  no cdp enable              ! Interface subcommand to override default



Two incorrect answers begin with a cdp enable command. The question describes a process of pasting the configuration into global config mode. However, IOS would reject the cdp enable command in this mode because it is not a valid IOS global command.

The other incorrect answer lists the no cdp run command after the interface G1/0/1 command. Even though in interface configuration mode, the IOS recognizes and accepts this valid global command - disabling CDP on all interfaces.

answerChoices.Text:
cdp run
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/1
  no cdp run

cdp enable
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/1
  no cdp enable

cdp enable
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/1
  no cdp run

cdp run
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/1
  no cdp enable

questionText: A router configuration includes the logging console 4 and logging monitor 7 commands. User 1 is connected via the console, User 2 is connected via Telnet, and User 3 is connected via SSH. On all appropriate sessions, terminal monitor has been configured. User 2 issues debug ip packets. Which user(s) sees the debug messages?
explanation:
By default, all log messages are shown to console users for all severity levels of messages. For this situation the defaults have been changed to logging console 4 and logging monitor 7, which makes these debug messages not display on the console line and instead display via Telnet and SSH, if terminal monitor is configured. The sessions that would see the debug messages are User 2 (Telnet) and User 3 (SSH) because they both have terminal monitor enabled during their sessions.

For User 1, the logging console 4 configuration changes the default behavior so that no debug messages are shown on the console port.

questionText: Which interface subcommand(s) enable LLDP to both transmit and receive LLDP messages?
explanation: To enable the use of LLDP on an interface in both directions, two different commands are required: the lldp transmit and lldp receive commands. Neither of the incorrect commands exist in IOS.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS configuration setting allows an engineer to locally view logging messages from a device at a later time, after the messages first occur?
explanation: A number of different commands must be entered (either by default or explicitly) to ensure messages are shown on the intended connection. The logging console and logging monitor commands are required to view real-time console and terminal output, respectively. The logging buffered command enables the recording of logging messages to the RAM of a device for later viewing.

questionText: What is correct about the state of the capabilities shown in this output?
explanation:
The show lldp neighbors output shows only the enabled capabilities on the neighbor devices, while the show cdp neighbors output shows all the possible capabilities on the neighbor devices, but that doesn’t mean they are enabled and in use.

	Based on the output of the show command, R1 is currently enabled for routing and SW1 is currently enabled for switching (bridge).

answerChoices.Text: SW2 can only ever have the capability of a bridge.
R1 can only ever have the capability of a router.
SW2 currently has its bridge capability enabled.
R1 currently has its router capability enabled.
R1 currently has its repeater capability enabled.
R1 currently has its bridge capability enabled.
SW2 currently has its router capability enabled.

questionText: The figure shows three switch ports with typical cabling with IP phones. One port connects an old Cisco phone, another a new Cisco phone, and another a non-Cisco phone. Which answers describe working methods for the phone to learn what VLAN ID to use as the voice VLAN for the phone’s traffic?
explanation:
