LAN switches dynamically inform attached IP phones what VLAN ID to use for the phone’s traffic on the pseudo-trunk between the switch and the phone. The original Cisco IP phones supported only Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) to declare the VLAN ID to the phone. Newer Cisco phones now support the standards-based LLDP-MED protocol for the same purpose – although they also support CDP. Non-Cisco phones never used the Cisco-proprietary CDP for learning phone settings, preferring LLDP from their earliest days.

As for the answers that mention static settings, the phones do not use a static setting for the voice VLAN on the link. Instead, they use CDP or LLDP-MED to learn the VLAN ID dynamically.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-003 from the 2023 exam updates question batcnh.

answerChoices.Text: On port G1/0/1, via static settings (phone configuration)
On port G1/0/2, via static settings (phone configuration)

questionText: Comparing LLDP to LLDP-MED, which answers make a claim that applies to LLDP-MED but not LLDP? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The LLDP standard has used type-length-value (TLV) data structures since its original definition. For instance, the original LLDP standard defined TLVs that allow one device to inform a neighboring device about the first device’s name and port numbers used.

Using TLVs allows for easy future expansion of LLDP. LLDP Media Endpoint Discovery (LLDP-MED) refers to a set of endpoint-focused TLVs. LLDP-MED includes the TLVs that enable switches to inform an attached IP phone what voice VLAN ID to use on the link. As another example, LLDP TLVs support the IEEE Power over Ethernet (PoE) standards so that the powered device (PD) can use LLDP-MED to inform the attached switch of its power needs.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-2-app-003 in the 2023 exam updates question batch

answerChoices.Text: Used to inform IP phones what voice VLAN to use on a link
Used to inform neighboring networking devices of local device facts, like port numbers
Used to inform a switch of an endpoint’s electrical power needs

questionText: Which syslog severity level is used for user-initiated debugs?
explanation: There are eight total message severity levels: 0 through 7. Severity level 0 messages are considered the most urgent and indicate that a system is unstable and in need of immediate attention. Severity level 7 messages are considered the least urgent and include the output from user-initiated debugs. The levels in between indicate various intermediary steps between those two extremes.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command is used to display all the known LLDP neighbors?
explanation: The show lldp neighbors command is similar in output to the show cdp neighbors command. However, instead of using the Cisco Discovery Protocol to discover those located off-local links from a device, it uses the Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP).

questionText: What is correct about the state of the shown capabilities in this output?
explanation:
The show lldp neighbors output shows only the enabled capabilities on the neighbor devices, while the show cdp neighbors output shows all the possible capabilities on the neighbor devices, but that doesn’t mean they are enabled and in use.

	Based on the output of the show command, SW2 is capable of running switching and IGMP and can enable only these capabilities. R1 is capable of running routing, switching, and IGMP and can enable only these capabilities. This doesn’t mean the capabilities are enabled.

	The rest of the options are incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: SW2 is capable of running switching and IGMP.
SW2 has switching and IGMP enabled.
R1 is capable of running routing, switching, and IGMP.
R1 has routing, switching, and IGMP enabled.
SW2 has switching enabled but IGMP not enabled.
R1 has routing enabled but switching and IGMP not enabled.
R1 can only ever have the capabilities of a router, switch, and IGMP.

questionText:
The text below lists five log messages per the output of the show logging command on a router. Which logging message level did IOS assign to the message that ends with “changed state to down”?


-	%LINK-5-CHANGED: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to administratively down
-	%LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN: Line protocol on Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to down
-	%SYS-5-CONFIG_I: Configured from console by console
-	%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to up 
-	OSPF-1 HELLO Gi0/1: Send hello to 224.0.0.5 area 0 from 172.16.1.1
explanation:
Cisco IOS logging defines eight message severity levels, each with a name and a matching numeric value (0-7). The following table lists the values:


	0-Emergency
	1-Alert
	2-Critical
	3-Error
	4-Warning
	5-Notification
	6-Informational
	7-Debug


The log messages embed the logging message level in the initial text code. The log message noted in the question begins with “%LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN”, identifying the message level as level 5, also known as notification.

questionText: A junior network engineer configured the CDP timer to be 180 seconds and the CDP holdtime timer to be 60 seconds. What is the outcome of this configuration?
explanation:
By default, CDP has a timer of 60 seconds, which means it sends a message to its neighbors every minute. CDP also has a holdtime timer that is 180 seconds by default. This holdtime timer is how long the device waits before removing the CDP neighbor information in the CDP table.

	The question has the timer values flipped from the default. The timer value is set to 180 and the holdtime timer is set to 60. Because of these values, there will not be enough time until the next CDP message is received before the holdtime timer is tripped, causing the CDP neighbor information to be flushed out of the CDP table before it’s even complete.

answerChoices.Text: Normal operation, because these are the default timers for CDP
Normal operation with non-default timers, with CDP neighbors up
No CDP neighbors, because the timer exceeds the holdtime timer
No CDP neighbors, because non-default timers are configured

questionText:
In layer 3 switch D2 in the figure, an engineer needs to disable CDP and LLDP on the G1/0/2 interface but enable them both on all the other interfaces. The output below lists all non-default configuration commands for CDP and LLDP. Which answer lists the briefest configuration that would meet the goals if pasting the configuration into global configuration mode? Reject any answers IOS would reject when pasting the commands into configuration mode. 


lldp run
interface G1/0/2
  no lldp receive
explanation:
You can achieve the stated goal by enabling CDP and LLDP by default while configuring the interface subcommands that disable CDP and LLDP on a particular interface, in this case, G1/0/1.

IOS defaults to use the cdp run and no lldp run global commands, enabling CDP and disabling LLDP globally. That means the interfaces use CDP unless an interface subcommand disables it (no cdp enable.) Conversely, with an LLDP global default of disabled, interfaces do not use LLDP unless an interface subcommand enables it (lldp transmit and lldp receive.)
However, the supplied configuration overrides the LLDP default, enabling LLDP globally with the lldp run global command. With those facts in mind, per the initial configuration, the question begins with the following:


	Both CDP and LLDP globally enabled
	LLDP partially disabled on G1/0/2
	CDP is fully functioning, and LLDP is partially functioning on G1/0/2


To disable CDP on the interface, use the no cdp enable interface subcommand, as seen in the correct answer. To disable LLDP on the interface, you need both the no lldp receive and no lldp transmit subcommands. The configuration already includes the first, so the correct answer adds the second of those commands.

Two incorrect answers list a command IOS will reject: no lldp enable. While IOS uses the no cdp enable interface subcommand to disable CDP on an interface, IOS does not support a no lldp enable interface subcommand. Those answers would not disable LLDP and would also show a command error when pasting the configuration.

Finally, consider the incorrect answer that begins with cdp run but which also has a no lldp transmit command. This answer makes the functions work as intended. However, it requires one additional command compared to the correct answer. The question asked for the briefest configuration that meets the goals, making this answer incorrect.

answerChoices.Text:
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp transmit

interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp enable

cdp run
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp enable

cdp run
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp transmit

questionText: Based on the capabilities shown, what is correct?
explanation:
With LLDP, there are two different capability classifications, what a device can support and what is currently enabled. The system capabilities in the show output are all the supported capabilities the device can and could have enabled. This does not mean that any of them are in fact enabled. The enabled capabilities is the list of the current enabled (configured) capabilities on that device.

	Based on the output of the show command, R1 has only the routing capability configured

	The rest of the options are incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: R1 has the routing and bridging capabilities configured.
R1 only supports the routing capability.
R1 only supports the bridging capability.
R1 only has the routing capability configured.

questionText: Which of the following commands list at least three lines of output per neighbor that describe information about a neighboring Cisco device?
explanation: The commands listed in the two correct answers list the same roughly 15 lines of information about a neighbor. The show cdp neighbors  command lists only a single line of summary information. The other  three answers list commands that list information about the operation of  CDP, as opposed to the information learned by CDP.
comments:
CD-I1-1-07-001-1

 

---

 

Should be placed in Chapter 33

questionText: The diagram shows a typical use of NAT and PAT, in which a router (R1) translates addresses from packets flowing between the Enterprise network on the left and the Internet on the right. Consider a packet sent by PC1 toward the web server, while the packet passes the LAN to the left of router R1. Which of the following statements are true about this packet and the network in general?
explanation:
The inside local address in this case is the address used for PC1 in packets that flow inside the Enterprise network. The inside global address is the address used to represent PC1 in packets as they flow through the global Internet. In a typical configuration, the address of the Internet-based host does not need to be changed. The packet shown in the figure is going from PC1 (inside the Enterprise) to the server, so the source IP address is an inside local IP address.

	By design, hosts inside the Enterprise typically use private IP addresses, with hosts in the Internet needing to use public IP addresses so that routers in the Internet know how to route the packets.
comments:
6/28 - ok as-is, "the NAT terms differ about a packet’s source address depending on where the packet is in its trip through the network. If you’d like to read more, check out Vol 2 Figure 10-4 and the paragraphs just before and after. So, when PC1 sends a packet, the source is PC1’s configured address, before the router applies NAT, that’s called the inside source address. Once the router applies source NAT and changes the address, the packet it somewhere between that NAT router and the destination in the Internet, and the source IP address is called an inside global address."

6/17, 5/28 - query to Au, CD-I2-7-56-002-1

answerChoices.Text: The packet’s source address is considered an inside local address.
The packet’s source address is considered an inside global address.
The address assigned to PC1 should be a private IP address.
The packet’s destination address should be a public IP address.

questionText: The diagram shows a typical use of NAT and PAT, in which a router (R1) translates addresses from packets flowing between the Enterprise network on the left and the Internet on the right. Consider a packet sent by a web server to PC1 as the packet passes from the Web server, through the Internet, towards R1. Which of the following statements are true about this packet?
explanation: The inside local address in this case is the address used for PC1 in  packets that flow inside the Enterprise network. The inside global  address is the address used to represent PC1 in packets as they flow  through the global Internet. The packet shown in the figure is going to  PC1, so the destination IP address is an inside global IP address.  Because the packet is currently flowing through the public Internet,  both the source and destination IP address are public IP addresses, with  R1 translating the destination IP address to PC1’s inside local IP  address before forwarding the packet into the Enterprise.

answerChoices.Text: The packet’s destination address is considered an inside local address.
The packet’s destination address is considered an inside global address.
Both the destination and source IP addresses would typically be public addresses.
At least one of the two IP addresses in the packet should be a private IP address.

questionText: Router R1 in the diagram needs to be configured for dynamic NAT, reserving public IP addresses 192.31.7.129 through 192.31.7.144 as a dynamic NAT pool for hosts in the 10.1.1.0/24 private IP subnet. Which of the following commands would be useful as part of the NAT configuration on R1?
explanation:
A complete configuration includes the following commands:

	 

	ip nat pool mypool 192.31.7.129 192.31.7.144 netmask 255.255.255.224

	ip nat inside source list 1 pool mypool

	!

	interface fa0/0

	 ip nat inside

	interface S0/0

	 ip nat outside

	!

	access-list 1 permit 10.1.1.0 0.0.0.255

	 

	Except for one answer, you can easily tell which answers list correct and incorrect configuration by comparing the answers to this configuration. The  ip nat pool mypool 192.31.7.129 192.31.7.144 netmask 255.255.255.240 global command is invalid because the netmask parameter checks to ensure that all the listed addresses are within the range of addresses implied by the listed subnet mask, when applied to the addresses in the range. In this case, mask 255.255.255.240, applied to 192.31.7.129, would give an address range of 192.31.7.128–192.31.7.143, including the subnet number and subnet broadcast address. Because the range includes the .144 address, this command would be rejected. The ip nat pool mypool 192.31.7.129 192.37.7.144 netmask 255.255.255.224 command, with mask 255.255.255.224, causes IOS to calculate a range of 192.31.7.128–159, which includes all the addresses, so the command would be accepted.
comments: 6/28 - query to Au, 8/31 - query to Au, CD-I2-7-57-002-2

answerChoices.Text: The ip nat inside interface subcommand under interface S0/0
The ip nat outside interface subcommand under interface S0/0
The ip nat pool mypool 192.31.7.129 192.31.7.144 netmask 255.255.255.240 global command
An access list that includes the single command access-list 1 permit 10.1.1.0 0.0.0.255
The ip nat inside source pool mypool list 1 global configuration command

questionText: What is the minimum requirement for NAT to allow users on subnet 192.168.1.0/24 to access resources on the Internet?
explanation:
The correct answer has all the ingredients for simple PAT with overloading on an existing outside interface IP address.

	Of the incorrect choices, one reference R1. If you performed NAT on that router, converting the network 192.168.1.0 addresses to use 10.0.0.1 (as would happen with the R1 configuration), NAT would work, but it would not allow traffic to flow back and forth to the Internet. The NAT solution needs to translate to the public IP address, in this case 23.0.0.2 as shown on R2's F0/1 interface.

	For the two incorrect answers that list R2 as the router: one is incorrect because the NAT inside and outside interfaces are reversed, while the other uses the wrong wildcard mask (255.0.0.0) in the ACL.

answerChoices.Text:
On R2:
int fa 0/0
 ip nat inside

int fa 0/1
 ip nat outside

access-list 1 permit 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255
ip nat inside source list 1 interface fastEthernet 0/1 overload

On R2:
int fa 0/0
 ip nat outside

int fa 0/1
 ip nat inside

access-list 1 permit 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255
ip nat inside source list 1 interface fastEthernet 0/1 overload

On R1:
int fa 0/1
 ip nat inside

int fa 0/0
 ip nat outside

access-list 1 permit 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255
ip nat inside source list 1 interface fastEthernet 0/0 overload

On R2:
int fa 0/0
 ip nat inside

int fa 0/1
 ip nat outside

access-list 1 permit 192.168.1.0 255.0.0.0
ip nat inside source list 1 interface fastEthernet 0/1 overload

questionText:
Which answers list correct conclusions that can be reached based on the information in the command output shown here?

R2#show ip nat translations
Pro   Inside global     Inside local       Outside local      Outside global
icmp  23.0.0.2:3        192.168.1.11:3     52.1.2.3:3         52.1.2.3:3
tcp   23.0.0.2:37874    192.168.1.11:37874 52.1.2.3:23        52.1.2.3:23
explanation:
The source IP is the inside local address, and is the same 192.168.1.11 for both the TCP and ICMP translations.

	ICMP does not use UDP. The host at 192.168.1.11 initiated Telnet to 52.1.2.3 to the well-known Telnet server port for Telnet TCP:23. The port number of 37874 was the source port from the user for the Telnet session.

answerChoices.Text: A host located at 192.168.1.11 issued a ping request to 23.0.0.2.
A host located at 192.168.1.11 sent an ICMP packet to UDP port number 3.
A host located at 23.0.0.2 initiated a telnet session to 52.1.2.3.
A host located at 23.0.0.2 initiated a telnet session to 192.168.1.11.
The source IP address for both translations is 192.168.1.11.
Port number 37874 is the destination port located at the Telnet server.

questionText: Considering the differences between NAT and PAT, which is the most accurate description?
explanation: Both NAT and PAT can support multiple protocols for each of their translations. PAT translates multiple inside local addresses into a single global address. PAT is also used with pools when there are more inside devices than addresses in the pool and the keyword overload has been used in the configuration.NAT is a one-to-one translation of IP to IP.

answerChoices.Text: NAT allows for multiple protocols across a single IP address.
NAT translates many IP addresses into a few or even one IP address.
PAT allows for multiple protocols across multiple IP addresses.
PAT translates many IP addresses into a few or even one IP address.

questionText: NAT translates a private address 192.168.1.1 to a public IP address 12.150.146.100. How would 192.168.1.1 be described?
explanation: The term inside refers to a host inside the Enterprise network, which often uses a private (RFC 1918) address inside the Enterprise. The term local refers to an address used for that host in the local, or Enterprise, network.

questionText: A colleague asked you to help troubleshoot a problem with their NAT/PAT configuration on router R1. NAT/PAT should translate packets sent by hosts in subnet 10.1.2.0/24 that are destined for the Internet. All translations should use R1's IP address in network 192.0.2.0 from the Internet link. (Consider network 192.0.2.0 to be a public IP network for this question.) Which answer identifies the action required to fix the configuration error?
explanation:
For the correct answer, as configured, ACL 1 matches only the address 10.1.2.2. The syntax shown in a standard ACL implies matching a host (a single IP address). The correct command, which matches all IP address in the subnet, is access-list 1 permit 10.1.2.0 0.0.0.255.

	For the incorrect answers, the ip nat inside command has no issues, and the ip nat inside and ip nat outside reside on the correct R1 interfaces. Moving the configuration to router R2 would not work because R2 has no public IP addresses to use, and the configuration, if moved as is, still has the configuration issue with access-list 1.

answerChoices.Text: Move this configuration to router R2 instead of router R1.
Swap the interfaces on which the ip nat inside and ip nat outside command are configured.

questionText: The internetworks created by Enterprises A and B both connect to the Internet, allowing all users to connect to hosts in the Internet and hosts in the other Enterprise. Enterprise C is totally isolated, not connecting to the Internet or to other companies. Which of the following are true about the use of public and private IP addresses in this scenario?
explanation: Private IP networks were originally intended for use inside  organizations that had no reason to connect to the Internet or to other  organizations. However, the looming IPv4 address shortage in the early  1990s required some solutions, one of which is NAT/PAT. PAT allows  organizations to use a small number of public IP addresses, assigning  private IP addresses to each individual host, with a device translating  addresses in packets sent to and from the Internet. This allows two  organizations to use the same IP address ranges and still be able to  communicate through the Internet.

answerChoices.Text: Enterprises A and B must assign public IP addresses to all hosts in their respective internetworks
Enterprises A and B can both use private IP networks, but they cannot use the same private network
Enterprise C can use any private network
Enterprises A and B can both use private network 10.0.0.0 as long as they also use NAT or PAT

questionText: For a particular NAT implementation, a private address 192.168.1.1 should always be translated with a 1:1 mapping to IP address 12.150.146.100. Which command accomplishes this?
explanation: You accomplish 1:1 static mapping with the ip nat inside source command, with the first IP address being the inside local address, and the second being the inside global address.

answerChoices.Text: ip nat inside source int s0 overload
ip nat inside source list 1 pool outside

questionText: Your company has configured all the internal IP addressing using private IP addresses. You then realize that some users will also want Internet access. What is the practical approach to solving this problem?
explanation: Using NAT at a perimeter router, and converting the private source addresses to global addresses before sending those packets into the public networks, would allow the internal users to access Internet resources.Using NAT to make the entire Internet appear as an inside local private address space is not reasonable. Assigning permanent static public IPs to individual hosts or dual homing those hosts just for Internet access is also not practical.

answerChoices.Text: Assign the internal hosts that need to access the Internet static public IP addresses on their workstations
Use a second network adapter on their workstation for the public access
Use NAT to make the Internet appear as local IP addresses, which are reachable by internal users
Configure translation to make the Internet believe the users have public addresses

questionText: You are the administrator of the network pictured in the figure. The exhibit shows the configuration for router A that a colleague has proposed. The goal of the configuration is to use PAT, translating addresses for hosts on router A's LAN, with a single global IP address from the serial 0 interface. Which of the following answers best describes what you must change for your colleague's configuration to correctly implement PAT?
explanation:
The configuration does have an issue (a fact that rules out one answer as incorrect). The correct answer lists the reason: the ip nat inside and ip nat outside commands were on incorrect interfaces.

	As for the other incorrect answers, they suggest changing the ip nat inside source command or the ACL used by NAT. Both are correct as is.

answerChoices.Text: Change the ip nat inside source command.
Reverse the location of the ip nat inside and ip nat outside commands.
The configuration works fine as is.

questionText: Which QoS options are recommended by Cisco when designing for a voice network?
explanation: Cisco recommends that when designing for a voice network, one-way delay is kept below 150 ms, jitter is kept below 30 ms, and loss is kept under 1%.

questionText: Which DSCP value is suggested to be used for packets that need low latency, low jitter, and low loss?
explanation: DiffServ defines the Expedited Forwarding (EF) Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) value for use on traffic that requires low latency, low jitter, and low loss.

questionText: Which options are not one of the manageable QoS characteristics of network traffic?
explanation: There are four QoS characteristics of network traffic: bandwidth, delay, jitter, and loss.

questionText: Which QoS feature is typically used outbound to an ISP to reduce the amount of traffic that is dropped by exceeding the purchased rate?
explanation: Often a connection to an Internet service provider (ISP) is physically connected with a technology that exceeds the purchased rate. To control the amount of traffic that is allowed onto their network, ISPs limit the rate that traffic is allowed to flow into the network. This is done with traffic policers; to limit the amount of traffic that could potentially be dropped by the ISP’s policer, an enterprise could choose to shape the traffic going out of their network and to the ISP.

questionText: What is the name of the IPv6 packet field that is used for marking DSCP values?
explanation: The IPv6 header includes the Traffic Class field that is used for marking traffic with Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) values.

questionText: Which QoS options are recommended by Cisco when designing for a video network?
explanation: Cisco recommends that when designing for a video network, one-way delay is kept below 400 ms (200 to 400 ms), jitter is kept below 50 ms (preferably lower than 30 ms), and loss is kept under 1%.

questionText: Which QoS feature is typically used inbound to a network to limit the amount of traffic that is allowed to flow in?
explanation: Typically traffic policers are used to control the flow of traffic coming into a network from a separate network (e.g., another company or customer). They do this by setting a limit to the amount of traffic that is allowed to be sent. There are a variety of ways that this rate can be configured, but generally a committed information rate (CIR) is used as an average measurement of allowed rate with an ability to allow for traffic spikes over short amounts of time.

questionText: What is the field that is used on modern systems that allows an IP packet to be marked with a specific QoS value?
explanation: On modern networks, the IP Type of Service field is split into two subfields: the Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) and the Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) field; of these, the DSCP is primarily used for marking traffic with a specific QoS value.

questionText: __________ means that the QoS tool changes one or more header fields, setting a value in the header.
explanation: Marking means that the QoS tool changes one or more header fields, setting a value in the header.

questionText: Which congestion management solution was designed specifically for voice and video that has specialized low delay, jitter, and loss requirements?
explanation: The Low Latency Queuing (LLQ) congestion management solution was designed specifically for traffic that has specific low delay, jitter, and loss requirements. LLQ provides preferential treatment for this traffic over other class-based queuing methods so that regardless of the current congestion conditions the traffic is forwarded.

questionText: The term _________ refers to the process of matching the fields in a message to make a choice to take some QoS action.
explanation: The term classification refers to the process of matching the fields in a message to make a choice to take some QoS action.

questionText: What is the name of the Cisco feature that allows for the identification of protocols that are traditionally hard to classify because of their operation?
explanation: Cisco’s Network Based Application Recognition (NBAR) and its successor NBAR2 allow for engineers to match protocols that have been traditionally very hard to classify because of their operation; an example includes the use of various dynamic ports.

questionText: Which QoS options are recommended by Cisco when designing for a voice network?
explanation: Cisco recommends that when designing for a voice network, one-way delay is kept below 150 ms, jitter is kept below 30 ms, and loss is kept under 1%.
comments: 12/13 - good as-is, 11/27 - query to Au, 5/12 - Good as-is, 5/9 - query to Au

questionText: Which DSCP marking group was created to be backward compatible with Internet Protocol Precedence (IPP) values?
explanation: DiffServ defines the Class Selector (CS) Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) as a set of values  designed to be backward compatible with Internet Protocol Precedence (IPP) numbering. IPP was used on networks before DSCPs were defined.

questionText: Which DSCP Assured Forwarding value provides the worst drop and worst queue performance?
explanation: DiffServ defines the Assured Forwarding (AF) Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) as a set of values that are used with each other. Traffic is separated into four different classes and three different drop priorities, resulting in a grid of 12 different AF values that are marked based on the intended use of the traffic. The AF13 marking results in traffic having the lowest queue priority and the highest drop probability.
comments: 4/12 - ok as-is, " You’d think AF11 would be worst and worst, respectively, particularly as it’s decimal value is the lowest number, but they didn’t do it that way. AF13 is indeed worst of all 12 AF values. See Figure 11-11 in Volume 2. EG, both AF11 and AF13 has the worst queuing preference. But AF11 is the best preference for drop, while AF13 is the worst, because AF13 has a higher percentage chance of being dropped compared to AFx1."   4/11 - query to Au

questionText: A router uses the low latency queuing (LLQ) feature on its WAN interface, with all voice packets using the priority queue and three data classes using non-priority queues. The WAN link becomes congested with both voice and data traffic. How does the router service the queues?
explanation:
Routers that use Low Latency Queuing (LLQ) always schedule the priority queue if packets exist in the queue. As a result, the other queues might suffer queue starvation when the link has too much load. To combat that issue, the LLQ feature also limits the amount of traffic that can be sent through the priority queue, discarding any excess traffic using a policing function, thereby leaving enough bandwidth for the non-priority queues.

	In this specific question, for the correct answers, the LLQ feature schedules the queue with priority scheduling for the priority queue, but with limits as implemented by policing. It also schedules the other queues in a round-robin fashion.

answerChoices.Text: Priority scheduling with no limits for voice
Priority scheduling with limits (policing) for voice
Round robin scheduling for the three data queues
Round robin scheduling for all four queues

questionText: Which answers list a feature of GLBP that is not true about VRRPv3 or HSRPv2?
explanation:
The question asks for answers that are true of GLBP but false of VRRPv3 or HSRPv2. The one correct answer notes a feature unique to GLBP among the three: The routers in the same group use unique MAC addresses.

Three incorrect answers list factual statements about GLBP that are also true about HSRP. The facts in those three answers include:


	Cisco proprietary
	Uses multicast address 224.0.0.102
	Requires the VIP to be different than any router’s interface address.


The other two incorrect answers list statements false about GLBP:


	GLBP does not support active/standby balancing but instead supports active/active.
	GLBP does not use MAC addresses beginning with 0000.0c, instead using addresses that begin 0007:b40.

answerChoices.Text: Uses a unique virtual MAC address per router in the same group
Routers must use different interface IP addresses as compared to the FHRP VIP
Supports active/standby load balancing within one group
Uses a virtual MAC address that begins 0000.0c

questionText: How many active routers can be forwarding at the same time with a single HSRP group?
explanation: HSRP works in an active/standby configuration where only a single router is forwarding at the same time within the same HSRP group.

questionText: There are two Layer 3 switches acting as core routers called SW1 and SW2. SW1 and SW2 have the IP addresses 192.168.1.1 and 192.168.1.2 on VLAN 10, respectively. If host 1 has a configured default gateway of 192.168.1.1 and SW1 were to have a failure that brings the device offline, what protocol should be implemented to mitigate this failure scenario?
explanation:
In a design situation like this, where VLANs are being spanned between multiple Layer 3 switches that have corresponding SVIs, you would want to implement a First Hop Redundancy Protocol, such as Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP). There is a specific failure situation if you do not implement a FHRP. With host 1 having a configured default gateway of SW1, and SW1 having a failure situation that brings the device offline, host 1 has essentially lost all connectivity outside the local area network (VLAN). If you were to implement a FHRP like HSRP, this situation would be mitigated because the default gateway address would be a virtual IP address and MAC address that is shared between both SW1 and SW2.

	STP prevents switching loops and should be used while also using any FHRP solution, with STP design considered with FHRP design. For example, the root bridge and secondary root bridge placements should be on SW1 and SW2 in the question to match the FHRP active and standby roles, respectively. With that said, STP is not the protocol that can resolve the issue with a default gateway going offline.

	Running an IGP is important but the issue at hand is more of a default gateway redundancy situation.

	BGP is not pertinent to this question.

questionText: In the figure, layer 3 switches D1 and D2 use HSRP for subnet 172.16.1.0/24 in the LAN. The figure summarizes the HSRPv2 settings on D1 and D2. D1 and D2 do not use interface tracking. In sequence, D1 boots up and holds an HSRP election. One month later, the staff powers on D2. Both correctly configure HSRP to use the same group with the same VIP of 172.16.1.9.  Which answers accurately describe the results of this HSRP configuration under the conditions described in the question? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Two answers discuss what happens during the first month of operation when only D1 works. HSRP, and all the FHRPs, work even a router realizes no other routers are participating in the group. D1 holds an HSRP election, finds no competition, wins, and becomes the HSRP active router.

For the other two related answers, you need to recall these facts about HSRP:


	It defaults to a priority value of 100.
	Higher priority wins the election.
	The preemption feature defaults to disabled.
	The per-device preemption setting defines that device’s ability to preempt (or not.) 


For the two answers that describe what happens after D2 powers up, note that neither layer 3 switch enables preemption. The question describes a classic case with a router joining the group after another router has been elected HSRP active (D1 in this case.) With preemption disabled, D2 does not attempt to take over the active role, even with a higher (better) HSRP priority.

answerChoices.Text: During the first month of operation, D1 becomes HSRP active and acts as VIP 172.16.1.9.
During the first month of operation, D1 rejects becoming HSRP active because no other routers exist in the subnet, so it does not act as VIP 172.16.1.9.
When D2 powers up, D2 becomes the HSRP active router.
When D2 powers up, D1 remains the HSRP active router.

questionText: An FHRP design scenario requires an active/standby solution that can load balance traffic per VLAN based. Which FHRP solution should be chosen?
explanation:
There are only two FHRP protocols listed, HSRP and GLBP. HSRP is an active/standby protocol while GLBP is an active/active protocol. In addition, HSRP load balances traffic per VLAN (subnet) while GLBP load balances traffic per host or end client.

	STP is used to mitigate switching loops and when utilizing FHRP solutions, STP should be designed at the same time. For example, root bridge and secondary root bridge placements should be on SW1 and SW2 in the question. With that said, STP is not the protocol that can resolve the issue with a default gateway going offline.

	SVIs are the default gateways for the VLANs in question.

questionText: The three routers all join one HSRP group for each of the three subnets in the figure. The virtual IP address the devices in VLAN 10 use is 10.0.0.50. VLAN 10 contains more than ten hosts, with PC1, PC2, and PC3 as examples. How many of the routers will be actively forwarding traffic for the VLAN 10 users?
explanation:
In HSRP, routers do not share the workload for a specific VLAN. If load balancing is wanted, a preference could be configured for each router to actively forward for a single subnet and provide standby service for the other VLANs. There is only one active forwarder per VLAN per group in HSRP.

Because the correct answer is one forwarder per VLAN/network, the other choices are not correct.

questionText: Which answers list a feature of VRRPv3 that is not true about either HSRPv2 or GLBP? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The question stem asks for answers true of VRRPv3 but also not true of HSRPv2 or GLBP. Of the listed answers, the two correct answers are true of VRRPv3 and untrue of the others. Of the incorrect answers:

•    Both HSRPv2 and GLBP, but not VRRPv3, use multicast address 224.0.0.102.
•    GLBP, but not others, uses virtual MAC addresses beginning with 0007.b4.
•    Both HSRPv2 and VRRPv3 support active/standby load balancing within one group.
•    VRRPv3  does not use a unique virtual MAC per router, instead sharing one virtual MAC address among all the routers in the group.

answerChoices.Text: Uses a unique virtual MAC address per router in the same group
The VIP may be identical to one of the group’s router interface IP addresses
Supports active/standby load balancing within one group
Uses a virtual MAC address that begins 0007.b4

questionText: Layer 3 switches D1 and D2 use GLBP with group number 20 and VIP 172.16.1.99. GLBP identifies layer three switch D1 as router 01 and D2 as router 02. All links in the figure work. The PCs use 172.16.1.99 as their default router. Which statement best describes how GLBP achieves load balancing? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
GLBP uses active/active load balancing within one GLBP group. To do so, one router or multilayer switch acts as the active virtual gateway (AVG), performing some important asks for the group. However, all routers (or multilayer switches) act as active virtual forwarders (AVFs), actively forwarding packets. (Those facts show the reasons for one correct and one incorrect answer.)

To allow multiple concurrent AVFs, each AVF uses a unique virtual MAC address. Over time, when different hosts ARP looking for the MAC address associated with the GLBP VIP, the AVG alternates replies, one with the virtual MAC of one of the AVFs, and the next for another AVF. By alternating the ARP responses, a subset of the hosts in the subnet refers to each AVF’s virtual MAC. So, a single host always sends packets to one AVF, but collectively the hosts send some packets to one AVF and some to the other.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-006 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

answerChoices.Text: Both multilayer switches act as an AVF to provide active/active load balancing.
Both multilayer switches act as an AVG to provide active/active load balancing.
Both multilayer implement the same virtual MAC address
Each multilayer switch implements a unique virtual MAC address

questionText: Which answers list a feature of HSRPv2 that is not true about VRRPv3 or GLBP?
explanation:
The question asks for answers true of HSRPv2 but also not true of VRRPv3 or GLBP. Of the listed answers, the one correct answer is the only one both true of HSRPv2 and untrue of the others. Of the incorrect answers:

•    Both HSRPv2 and GLBP are Cisco proprietary, use multicast address 224.0.0.102, and require the VIP to be different than any router’s interface address.
•    Both HSRPv2 and VRRPv3 support active/standby load balancing within one group.
•    HSRPv2 does not use a unique virtual MAC per router.

answerChoices.Text: Uses a unique virtual MAC address per router in the same group
The VIP cannot be the same as any of the routers’ interface IP addresses in the group
Supports active/standby load balancing within one group
Uses a virtual MAC address that begins 0000.0c

questionText: Which of the answers lists a feature of FTP?
explanation:
Compared to TFTP, FTP supports a more robust environment ready for use inside an enterprise and across the Internet. FTP supports user authentication, authorization for different server directories, and a means for users to navigate their context between other present working directories. It uses TCP as the transport protocol with well-known TCP ports 20 and 21. 

In contrast, TFTP requires far less code which can be helpful in some environments. It uses UDP with well-known port 69. Given its role as a lightweight tool for IT staff, it has few features, expecting the IT personnel to place the files on the server, stopping and starting the TFTP server only as needed.

answerChoices.Text: Allows the user to navigate server directories

questionText: Which is an unsolicited message from an SNMP agent that requires acknowledgement from a Network management station (NMS)?
explanation: SNMP provides two options for the sending of unsolicited messages from a managed device to the NMS. Devices send trap messages with no acknowledgment that the NMS received the message; using protocol terminology, these messages are considered unreliable. A later version of SNMP (Version 2) supports an alternative process with inform messages, which use an acknowledgment process, so they are called reliable.

questionText: A network has SNMPv3 implemented throughout with an NMS deployed to assist with monitoring and management. How would one of the network devices in the network authenticate to the NMS?
explanation:
SNMPv3 made some signification changes to how SNMP functioned from a security standpoint compared to SNMPv2 and SNMPv1. SNMPv3 got rid of communities altogether and replaced them with usernames and passwords. On some devices there are also groups, roles, and views to help structure a role-based policy with the SNMPv3 deployment.

	SNMPv1 and SNMPv2 utilized RO and RW community strings.

answerChoices.Text: Utilizing a username and password combination

questionText: A user connects to the CLI of a Cisco router and immediately moves to privileged mode. They then issue the dir and show flash: commands in succession. Which answers describe facts true of only the dir command but not accurate of the show flash: command in this scenario?
explanation:
IOS keeps an environment variable for the present working directory (pwd) in the IOS filesystem. The IOS dir command lists files and directories in the pwd, but not files in any subdirectories, much like a Windows or Linux shell dir or ls command. Using the cd command, any user who has not changed their pwd to another directory begins with a pwd set to the bootflash:/ directory. (IOS also creates flash: as an alias for bootflash:.) So, the show flash: EXEC command displays the contents of the bootflash: directory with different formatting and detail compared to the dir command. In particular:


	The dir command lists files and directories in the pwd but not files located in those subdirectories. The show flash: command lists all files – those in the pwd plus all in subdirectories.
	The two commands list used and free space in the filesystem differently. The show flash: command lists bytes used and bytes available, while dir lists total bytes and bytes free (available.)

answerChoices.Text: It lists files in the present working directory but not files in subdirectories
It lists files in the flash:/ directory but not in subdirectories
It lists files in the present working directory and all subdirectories
It lists files in the flash:/ and all subdirectories

questionText: Which implementations of SNMP includes authentication, data integrity, and encryption?
explanation:
Only SNMPv3 includes data integrity, authentication, and encryption.

	All older flavors of SNMP do not have all three elements listed in the question.

questionText: What features did SNMPv3 replace communities with?
explanation:
SNMPv3 made some signification changes to how SNMP functioned from a security standpoint when compared to SNMPv2 and SNMPv1. SNMPv3 got rid of communities altogether and added the following capabilities:

	
		Message integrity
	
		Authentication
	
		Encryption


	Authorization and accounting are not capabilities or features that SNMPv3 meets.

questionText: Which of the answers lists a feature of TFTP?
explanation:
Compared to TFTP, FTP supports a more robust environment ready for use inside an enterprise and across the Internet. FTP supports user authentication, authorization for different server directories, and a means for users to navigate their context between other present working directories. It uses TCP as the transport protocol with well-known TCP ports 20 and 21. 

In contrast, TFTP requires far less code which can be helpful in some environments. It uses UDP with well-known port 69. Given its role as a lightweight tool for IT staff, it has few features, expecting the IT personnel to place the files on the server, stopping and starting the TFTP server only as needed.

answerChoices.Text: Allows the user to navigate server directories

questionText: What commands does TFTP support?
explanation: TFTP has very limited functionality compared to FTP because it was meant to be a lightweight protocol. Because of this, TFTP only supports Get files and Put files, while FTP supports a long list of commands and capabilities.

questionText: What is used as an identifier for each variable in the MIB in the SNMP framework?
explanation: The Management Information Base (MIB) defines variables, and those variables enable the management software to monitor/control the network device. Formally, the MIB defines each variable as an object ID (OID). The MIB then organizes the OIDs based on RFC standards into a hierarchy of OIDs, usually shown as a tree.

questionText: Which TCP/IP protocol and port does TFTP utilize?
explanation: TFTP uses UDP 69. FTP uses TCP 21 and TCP 20.

questionText:
A user in privileged EXEC mode confirms their present working directory in the IOS file system on a router is bootflash:. They then issue the sequence of commands below and press enter when given any prompts by the commands. Following that, the user repeats several variations of the dir command as shown in the answers. Which answers accurately describe the files listed by each dir command?


copy running-config backup1.txt
mkdir backups
copy running-config backup2.txt
explanation:
The dir EXEC command lists files in the directory listed in the command. If the command lists no directory, it uses the directory per the present working directory environment variable, as seen by the pwd EXEC command. Given the facts for this question, the dir command (without a directory parameter) lists files in the bootflash: base directory, while the dir bootflash:/backups command lists files in the /backups subdirectory. Also, note that the dir command lists files in the specific directory but does not list the files found in subdirectories.

Next, consider the sequence of events with the three commands issued by the engineer. Both copy commands list the second filename with no directory and just the filename (backup1.txt and backup2.txt). As a result, these copy commands copy the file into the present working directory. Given that the user did not change their pwd using the pwd command, both commands copy files into the pwd, namely bootflash: As a result, both files reside in the bootflash: directory in this scenario.

answerChoices.Text: The dir bootflash:/backups command lists file backup1.txt.
The dir bootflash:/backups command lists file backup2.txt.

questionText: What is the database of variables on a network device that can be polled or manipulated in Simple Network Management Protocol operations?
explanation: The Management Information Base is the database of variables on a network device that can be used for Simple Network Management Protocol. An SNMP management station is used to poll the SNMP agent on the device. This agent reads or writes to the variables stored in the MIB. An SNMP trap is an unsolicited message sent by the SNMP agent to indicate a variable’s value from the MIB.

questionText: A network contains Cisco routers and some from another vendor (Vendor X.) The network uses Cisco DNA Center to manage the network – a product that uses SNMP to manage the routers. Which answers describe the most likely case for loading MIB definitions into DNS Center to support the managed devices?
explanation: SNMP managers need a MIB definition that defines the format of all variables used on the agents they manage. SNMP managers come pre-loaded with MIBs. However, they also support the ability to load MIBs into the SNMP manager to support products whose MIBs they might not have pre-loaded when building the product. Cisco DNA Center will come pre-loaded with all the Cisco-proprietary MIBs and the RFC-defined MIB-II in this case. However, the staff must be ready to recognize when managing other vendors’ products and load the related MIB definitions into the SNMP manager.

answerChoices.Text: Load a MIB of Cisco variables
Load a MIB of vendor X variables
No additional MIB loading will be required

questionText: Which UTP transmission speeds did the IEEE add to create the multigig Ethernet? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Multigig Ethernet introduced two new speeds: 2.5 Gbps and 5.0 Gbps. Before introducing multigig in the mid-2010s, the IEEE had released 1000BASE-T (late 1990s) and 10GBASE-T (mid-2000s). The popular 1000BASE-T standard required Cat 5E cabling, and many building owners deployed Cat 5E from wiring closets to locations on each floor. 10GBASE-T requires Cat 6A cabling to reach distances up to 100 meters—that requirement forced building owners to consider upgrading the Ethernet cabling plant at some expense.

The IEEE engineered two new Ethernet speeds between 1 Gbps and 10 Gbps that work over the same cabling as 1000BASE-T (Cat 5E) at the same 100-meter distance. Those speeds are 2.5 and 5.0 Gbps. As for the incorrect answers, the IEEE has standards for 10 Gbps using UTP cabling (10GBASE-T). To date, the IEEE does not have UTP-based standards for 2 and 20 Gbps.

questionText: A switch with several PoE ports powers up. All ports that support PoE use automatic detection of whether to supply power or not. Which answer best describes how the switch moves from supplying no power at all to providing some power over the cable?
explanation:
To review the terms, PD represents Powered Device, referring to the device that needs power. PSE means Power Sourcing Equipment, referring to the switch that supplies power to the PD over the Ethernet cable.

The question asks about automatic detection for the initial power levels. That process uses the sensing of electrical signals. The PSE and PD create a circuit, with the PSE inducing a current on the circuit. The PD changes the signal by applying a specific amount of resistance. The returning signal, reduced by the electrical resistance applied by the PD, signals to the PSE that a PD exists. Knowing a PD exists, the PSE can supply a small initial current, just enough to allow the PD to initialize enough software to ask for additional power via layer two messages using CDP and LLDP.

answerChoices.Text: The PSE completes a circuit and monitors for specific resistance the PD applies.
The PD completes a circuit and monitors for specific resistance the PSE applies.
The PD sends a CDP or LLDP message to the PSE specifying the power level to apply.
The PSE sends a CDP or LLDP message to the PD specifying the power level to apply.

questionText: Which of these IEEE Ethernet standards requires a UTP cable category 5E or better for distances up to 100 meters?
explanation:
The IEEE defines a cable category requirement for their various UTP-based physical layer standards. The minimum cable categories for the standards referenced in the answers are:


	
		
			
			Standard
			
			
			Minimum Cable Category
			
		
	
	
		
			
			10BASE-T
			
			
			CAT 3
			
		
		
			
			100BASE-T
			
			
			CAT 5
			
		
		
			
			1000BASE-T
			
			
			CAT5E
			
		
		
			
			10GBASE-T
			
			
			CAT6A
			
		
		
			
			40GBASE-T
			
			
			CAT 8

questionText: Which of these IEEE Ethernet standards requires a UTP cable category 6A or better for distances up to 100 meters?
explanation:
The IEEE defines a cable category requirement for their various UTP-based physical layer standards. The minimum cable categories for the standards referenced in the answers are:


	
		
			
			Standard
			
			
			Minimum Cable Category
			
		
	
	
		
			
			10BASE-T
			
			
			CAT 3
			
		
		
			
			100BASE-T
			
			
			CAT 5
			
		
		
			
			1000BASE-T
			
			
			CAT5E
			
		
		
			
			10GBASE-T
			
			
			CAT6A
			
		
		
			
			40GBASE-T
			
			
			CAT 8

questionText: Match the two-tier topology designs with their definitions.
explanation: Here are diagram examples of each two-tier topology:

questionText: A SOHO device has which capabilities?
explanation:
SOHOs traditionally have few requirements, so to meet these needs numerous capabilities are merged into a single physical device to allow for a more efficient and effective solution. Specifically, the SOHO device is also the Ethernet switch, wireless AP, router, and firewall for the small office/home office setup.

	Today, the SOHO device does not act as the host device.

questionText: The two-tier LAN design solves which two major design requirements?
explanation:
The two-tier campus LAN architecture meets two primary goals: connecting end user devices and properly scaling out the connectivity between the access layer to the distribution layer.

	The two incorrect answers describe the benefits of using a three-tier design, particularly the role of including the core level in the architecture.

answerChoices.Text: Reduce the number of switch-to-switch links
Scalable connectivity from access to distribution
Scalability issues for the largest campus LANs

questionText: Which OM cable type uses a 50-micrometer core? (Choose three answers.)
explanation: Optical Multimode (OM) fiber optic cabling supports various Ethernet standards. The first of these, OM1, uses a wider core/cladding (62.5/125 micrometer) than the more recent OM ratings (OM2, OM3, OM4) which use 50/125 micrometer core/cladding.

questionText: After completing layer 1 power classification, how does a PoE LAN switch choose the final power classification to use, determining the continuous power to apply to the link? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
PoE attempts dynamic power classification so that the switch learns the correct power class to use and can even vary that class over time if the needs of the device change. The switch uses layer 2 power classification with CDP or LLDP messages. (CDP and LLDP messages do not use or rely on IP, so they are considered layer 2 messages, which is why the mechanism is called layer 2 power classification.)

For the incorrect answers, PoE switches do not use a PoE API. Also, applying the maximum power to the port risks applying too much power – instead, the more considered dynamic layer 2 messaging approach reduces the risk of harming the powered device.

answerChoices.Text: By using the maximum power allowed by the switch port
The powered device informs the switch using CDP messages
The powered device informs the switch using LLDP messages
The powered device signals utilizing the switch’s PoE API

questionText: In a three-tier design, what is name for the tier at the center of the network?
explanation: In a three-tier design the third tier is called the core tier. It interconnects the different pods with the architecture.

questionText: IEEE introduced multigig Ethernet to solve issues with then-current UTP-based Ethernet standards. Which answer describes one of the problems solved by multigig Ethernet?
explanation:
Multigig Ethernet introduced two new speeds: 2.5 Gbps and 5.0 Gbps. Before introducing multigig in the mid-2010s, the IEEE had released 1000BASE-T (late 1990s) and 10GBASE-T (mid-2000s). The popular 1000BASE-T standard required Cat 5E cabling, and many building owners deployed Cat 5E from wiring closets to locations on each floor. 10GBASE-T requires Cat 6A cabling to reach distances up to 100 meters—that requirement forced building owners to consider upgrading the Ethernet cabling plant at some expense.

The IEEE engineered two new Ethernet speeds between 1 Gbps and 10 Gbps that work over the same cabling as 1000BASE-T (Cat 5E) at the same 100-meter distance. Those speeds are 2.5 and 5.0 Gbps. As for the incorrect answers, the IEEE has standards for 10 Gbps using UTP cabling (10GBASE-T). To date, the IEEE does not have UTP-based standards for 2 and 20 Gbps.

answerChoices.Text: Achieving speeds faster than 1 Gbps using Cat 5E cabling
Achieving speeds faster than 1 Gbps using Cat 6A cabling
Achieving speeds faster than 100 Mbps using Cat 5E cabling
Achieving speeds than 100 Mbps using Cat 6A cabling

questionText: The different PoE standards all utilize a different number of wire pairs to send power to the end device. Of the standards below, which of them use two wire pairs to send power?
explanation:
PoE and PoE+ all use two wire pairs to send power to the end device.

The UPoE and UPoE+ standards use four wire pairs to send power to the end device.

questionText: Which switch campus three-tier topology role provides an aggregation point for the switches that connect directly to end user devices?
explanation: When a three-tier switched campus design is implemented, three traditional layers are used: core, distribute, and access. The core layer aggregates the distribution layer switches and provides a very high speed connection. The distribution layer provides an aggregation point for access layer switches and provides connectivity to the rest of the devices in the LAN. The access layer provides a connection point for end-user devices but does not typically connect together access layer switches directly under normal circumstances.

questionText: Per standard, which OM cable types does 10 Gbps Ethernet (10GBASE-SR) support for distances of 200 meters?
explanation: Optical Multimode (OM) fiber optic cabling supports various Ethernet standards. The IEEE 10BASE-SR standard allows for the use of OM1, OM2, OM3, and OM4, with OM3 rated for 300 meters and OM4 for 400 meters. OM1 and OM2 support 33 and 82 meters per the standard, respectively.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-007 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

questionText: Which OM cable type uses a 62.5-micrometer core?
explanation: Optical Multimode (OM) fiber optic cabling supports various Ethernet standards. The first of these, OM1, uses a wider core/cladding (62.5/125 micrometer) than the more recent OM ratings which use 50/125 micrometer core/cladding.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-2-app-007 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

questionText: The different PoE standards all utilize a different number of wire pairs to send power to the end device. Of the following standards, which use four wire pairs to send power?
explanation:
UPoE and UPoE+ are the standards that use four wire pairs to send power to the end device.

PoE, and PoE+ use two wire pairs to send power to the end device.

questionText: Which layer of a three-tier campus LAN topology provides a connection point for end-user devices?
explanation: When a three-tier switched campus design is implemented, three traditional layers are used: core, distribute, and access. The core layer aggregates the distribution layer switches and provides a very high speed connection. The distribution layer provides an aggregation point for access layer switches and provides connectivity to the rest of the devices in the LAN. The access layer provides a connection point for end-user devices but does not typically connect together access layer switches directly under normal circumstances.

questionText: Each answer lists two Metro Ethernet terms. Which answer(s) lists two terms that both refer to the same Metro Ethernet service?
explanation: There are three different MEF-defined Metro Ethernet services: Ethernet Line Service (E-Line), Ethernet LAN Service (E-LAN), and Ethernet Tree Service (E-Tree). E-Line is used to connect two devices that can exchange Ethernet frames similarly to a point-to-point link. E-LAN acts similarly to a local LAN (full mesh) and allows all devices to directly connect to each other. E-Tree resembles a hub-and-spoke topology and allows a “hub” device to communicate with all “spoke” devices, but the “spokes” are not able to directly communicate without being relayed through the “hub.”

questionText: Which of the following is not considered a security benefit of using Internet VPNs?
explanation: Accounting (logging) functions are useful for security purposes, but they are not an inherent feature of Internet VPN features.

questionText: What are the benefits of using IPsec as an addition to your packets that are being sent across a network?
explanation: IPsec uses several technologies including encryption algorithms and authentication methods to provide privacy and authentication. The sequence numbers within ESP also provide protection against someone capturing the data and replaying it later to fool one or both of the VPN peers.IPsec itself does not provide for multilink or compression.

questionText: Routers can use the same 5G technology advertised for mobile phones to communicate. 5G standards include an option that works with the mobile carriers' older 4G LTE networks but with slightly faster speeds. 5G supports another option that does not use the older 4G LTE technology but supports must faster speeds. Which answers list a term used for the slower 5G option? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
5G defines some parts of the standard to aid the migration away from the prior generation so that mobile carriers can use their existing infrastructure while rolling out 5G technology. This 5G subset uses some of the same protocols and technology as 4G LTE and goes by 5G Non-standalone (NSA) wireless, or sub-6. The reference to non-standalone refers to using the older 4G LTE network. The sub-6 term refers to the fact that it uses frequencies just below 6 GHz. 

In contrast, 5G Standalone (SA) wireless (mmWave) ignores the older 4G technologies, requiring carriers to invest in new equipment and software. However, it provides must faster speeds. The word standalone means it does not rely on the older 4G network. The mmWave term, instead of frequency, refers to wavelengths – the wavelengths used by this part of 5G are millimeters (mm) long.

questionText: What is the name of the MetroE concept that defines which user devices can communicate with each other?
explanation: The MetroE Ethernet Virtual Connection (EVC) concept defines which user devices can communicate with each other; for example, an E-Line service defines a single EVC as it only connects together two devices, whereas an E-Tree service could define multiple EVCs depending on the number of “spoke” devices.

questionText: When referencing MPLS VPN Layer 3 configurations, which of the following statements are true?
explanation: When configuring an MPLS VPN the CE and the PE routers can become routing protocol neighbors using a variety of different protocols; but regardless of the protocol used to connect with the CE, Multiprotocol BGP (MP-BGP) is used to transport the customer routes across the provider’s network. The CE routers will not form neighborships with each other in this configuration.

answerChoices.Text: The CE router becomes a routing protocol neighbor with the PE.
The provider uses MP-BGP to transport customer routes.
The provider can use any routing protocol to transport customer routes.
The CE router becomes a routing protocol neighbor with the remote CE.

questionText: Which answers list an attribute of remote access VPNs? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
A site-to-site VPN connects two sites by creating a tunnel between two IT-controlled devices (routers, firewalls, or network access servers.) The VPN remains up and working under normal conditions. The endpoint hosts have no awareness of the existence of the VPN, with IP routing forwarding packets over the VPN and the VPN features encrypting the data. All devices at a site can send traffic over the site-to-site VPN. The two incorrect answers refer to attributes of site-to-site VPNs.

Remote access VPNs support a single device. Sometimes, the host uses VPN client software to create an encrypted VPN connection to a remote site. For instance, a remote worker can use a VPN client on their laptop to create a secure VPN tunnel to the corporate network over the Internet. That VPN supports all packets sent by that one host but not for other hosts at the site. The user at that host can connect with the VPN software, use the connection, and stop it later as needed, as an on-demand service.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-008 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

answerChoices.Text: Supports all the devices at one site for all traffic sent by each device
Supports one device at a site but for all traffic sent by that device
Typically established beforehand and left active at all times

questionText: Refer to the diagram; which option is the term used to reference the devices indicated with a green arrow?
explanation: MPLS VPNs use the term customer edge (CE) to reference the customer device that directly connects to the provider; the provider router that connects to the CE is referred to as the provider edge (PE) device.

questionText: Which of the following are true about VPNs?
explanation:
Remote-access and site-to-site VPNs are often used as a less-expensive option to traditional WANs. IPsec provides authentication, data integrity, and confidentiality.

AnyConnect is used for remote-access VPNs. VPNs do not remove the requirement for local authentication at the user computer by the user. TLS and IPsec are similar in their benefits but different with regard to the technology they use and different in their use.

answerChoices.Text: Remote-access and site-to-site VPNs are often used as a less-expensive option to traditional WANs.
AnyConnect is an example of software that would be used in a site-to-site VPN solution.
VPNs remove the need for users to manually log in to their computers each morning.
IPsec provides authentication, data integrity, and confidentiality.
TLS and IPsec are the same basic technology and are used for the same types of VPNs.

questionText: Which of the following VPN features provides encryption and authentication services, but only for applications accessible from the user’s web browser?
explanation: Transport LAyer Security (TLS), which replaced Secure Socket Layer (SSL), is included in popular web browsers, providing VPN capability from a web browser without the need for VPN client software.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; what is the term that is used to reference the link indicated with the green arrows?
explanation: The term user network interface (UNI) refers to a link between the provider network and a customer (user) network.

questionText: Two geographically-separated sites in an enterprise have 20-plus devices each, an Internet connection, and no private WAN links. What Internet-based VPN technology should be used to connect these two sites?
explanation:
Of the three answers that could be used over the Internet, site-to-site VPNs work best with multiple devices at each site. A site-to-site VPN creates one tunnel, configured on two devices, one at each location. Once the tunnel is functional, all devices at each site can communicate with devices in the other site.

The remote access VPN options using either IPsec or TLS would not be best given the design. Both require each device to create their own VPN tunnel to each other device. Doing so in this case would require extra unnecessary work and would be difficult to scale and manage long term.

The other incorrect answer, MPLS VPN, uses a private WAN (MPLS) rather than the Internet, so it does not meet the requirements listed in the question.

questionText: Which statements are most accurate about using IPsec tunnel mode instead of transport mode? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
IPsec tunnel mode refers to the scope of encryption. With tunnel mode, the VPN endpoints receive packets created by other hosts. After receiving a packet, if the routing choice directs the packet over the VPN tunnel, the sender encrypts the original unencrypted IP packet. The sender creates a new IP packet with a new IP header. The source and destination of the new packet use the VPN tunnel devices’ addresses as the source and destination of the packet. The original encrypted packet resides as data in the new packet. Once the receiving tunnel endpoint receives the packet, it extracts the data, which holds the encrypted original IP packet, and decrypts it.

Tunnel mode works well for site-to-site VPNs. Site-to-site VPNs must support traffic from many hosts with different IP addresses. Encrypting and later decrypting the original IP packet preserves the original source and destination IP addresses, making it easy to forward the packets after they exit the VPN tunnel.

The two incorrect answers describe IPsec transport mode. It works well for remote access VPNs for which one VPN connection supports, at most, a single host. One site has only one IP address to serve, implied as one of the tunnel endpoints. So, transport mode, which uses fewer overhead bytes, works well for IPsec remote access VPNs.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-2-app-008 from the 2023 Exam Updates question bank

answerChoices.Text: More typically used by IPsec site-to-site VPNs
More typically used by IPsec remote access VPNs
Encrypts the original IP packet, including the original IP header
Encrypts the data of the original IP packet but not the original IP header

questionText: Which answers list an attribute of site-to-site VPNs? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
A site-to-site VPN connects two sites by creating a tunnel between two IT-controlled devices (routers, firewalls, or network access servers.) The VPN remains up and working under normal conditions. The endpoint hosts have no awareness of the existence of the VPN, with IP routing forwarding packets over the VPN and the VPN features encrypting the data. All devices at a site can send traffic over the site-to-site VPN. The two incorrect answers refer to attributes of site-to-site VPNs.

Remote access VPNs support a single device. Sometimes, the host uses VPN client software to create an encrypted VPN connection to a remote site. For instance, a remote worker can use a VPN client on their laptop to create a secure VPN tunnel to the corporate network over the Internet. That VPN supports all packets sent by that one host but not for other hosts at the site. The user at that host can connect with the VPN software, use the connection, and stop it later as needed, as an on-demand service.

answerChoices.Text: Supports all the devices at one site for all traffic sent by each device
Supports one device at a site but for all traffic sent by that device
Typically established beforehand and left active at all times

questionText: Which MEF-defined Metro Ethernet service acts similarly to a local LAN?
explanation: There are three different MEF-defined Metro Ethernet services: Ethernet Line Service (E-Line), Ethernet LAN Service (E-LAN), and Ethernet Tree Service (E-Tree). E-Line is used to connect two devices that can exchange Ethernet frames similarly to a point-to-point link. E-LAN acts similarly to a local LAN and allows all devices to directly connect to each other. E-Tree resembles a hub-and-spoke topology and allows a “hub” device to communicate with all “spoke” devices, but the “spokes” are not able to directly communicate without being relayed through the “hub.”

questionText: Routers can use the same 5G technology advertised for mobile phones to communicate. 5G standards include an option that works with the mobile carriers' older 4G LTE networks but with slightly faster speeds. 5G supports another option that does not use the older 4G LTE technology but supports must faster speeds. Which answers list a term used for the faster 5G option? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
5G defined some parts of the standard to aid the migration away from the prior generation so that mobile carriers can use their existing infrastructure while rolling out 5G technology. This 5G subset uses some of the same protocols and technology as 4G LTE and goes by 5G Non-standalone (NSA) wireless, or sub-6. The reference to non-standalone refers to using the older 4G LTE network. The sub-6 term refers to the fact that it uses frequencies just below 6 GHz.

In contrast, 5G Standalone (SA) wireless (mmWave) ignores the older 4G technologies, requiring carriers to invest in new equipment and software. However, it provides much faster speeds. The word standalone means it does not rely on the older 4G network. The mmWave term, instead of frequency, refers to wavelengths – the wavelengths used by this part of 5G are millimeters (mm) long.

questionText: Which MEF-defined Metro Ethernet service has been previously referenced by the name Virtual Private Wire Service?
explanation: There are three different MEF-defined Metro Ethernet services: E-Line (Ethernet Line Service), E-LAN (Ethernet LAN Service), and E-Tree (Ethernet Tree Service). E-Line is used to connect two devices that can exchange Ethernet frames similarly to a point-to-point link; it has also been referred to by the name Virtual Private Wire Service. E-LAN acts similarly to a local LAN and allows all devices to directly connect to each other; it has also been referred to by the name Virtual Private LAN Service. E-Tree resembles a hub-and-spoke topology and allows a “hub” device to communicate with all “spoke” devices, but the “spokes” are not able to directly communicate without being relayed through the “hub.”

questionText: Migrating your on-premise email capability to a cloud-hosted email service offering is an example of what as a service model?
explanation:
A cloud-hosted email service is a perfect example of a Software as a Service offering.

	Infrastructure as a Service is an offering that provides a system, or multiple systems, that the consumer can leverage as needed. Usually these systems have an operating system pre-installed but then the consumer needs to install any applications and tools they need to complete their work.

	Platform as a Service is the next step after Infrastructure as a Service. Platform as a Service also includes a system, or multiple systems, that can be leveraged as needed with a pre-installed operating system. The difference between IaaS and PaaS is that PaaS will have the needed tools and applications pre-installed as well.

	IT as a Service is offloading all of your IT systems, infrastructure, and services to a company that manages them for you.

questionText: Of the different public cloud WAN options, which can be utilized to rapidly deploy a public cloud?
explanation: The Internet and Internet VPN options can be used to rapidly deploy a public cloud. The other options, Ethernet WAN, MPLS VPN, and Intercloud Exchange, take significantly more time to stand up.

questionText: What option(s) are required criteria for a service to be a cloud service?
explanation:
Five specific criteria are required for a service to be a cloud service:

	
		On-demand self-service: You determine when you want and do not want a service.
	
		Broad network access: The cloud service must be accessible by numerous connectivity options and a fast number of devices should be able to leverage it.
	
		Resource pooling: Instead of assigning dedicated resources, such as memory and CPU, to each system, resources can be shared across a set of services, servers, and systems. These shared resources are then dynamically allocated on-demand as a system needs it.
	
		Rapid elasticity: A cloud service is very different from an on-premise virtual environment. There are still capabilities like resource pooling on-premise, but with rapid elasticity it’s hard to come by. Rapid elasticity makes the pools of resources seem unlimited. New resource requests are completed rapidly.
	
		Measured service: In a cloud service, utilization is tracked and monitored, which can then be reported on by the operator. This is used for billing but also can be used for other capabilities if needed by an organization.


	Both agile network access and proactive service are unrelated to a cloud service offering and refer to business architecture principals.

questionText: Which cloud service is specific to one company that owns both the tools/infrastructure that creates the cloud and employs the people that use the services?
explanation: A private cloud is defined as a service that is private to a single company that owns and operates the infrastructure and employs the people that will be requesting and using the services offered. A public cloud, on the other hand, is a service that is owned and operated by a third party, but with the people that request and use the service being employees of a number of different companies that choose to use the service.

questionText: Which of the following options are available to configure the Cisco 8000V router and provide access to the CLI via a hypervisor?
explanation: There are two options to connect to the console of a Cisco 8000V virtual router inside a hypervisor: virtual console access via the virtual VGA console within the hypervisor, and serial console access, which is available via the UNIX xTerm terminal. The other two options are incorrectly listed.

answerChoices.Text: Serial console via the virtual VGA console
Virtual console via the virtual VGA console
Virtual console via the UNIX xTerm terminal
Serial console via the UNIX xTerm terminal

questionText: Which public cloud WAN connection options do not offer the ability to have reliable QoS?
