explanation: Any solution that is based on the Internet as a transport will not be able to guarantee quality of service (QoS), because the Internet itself is based on a best-effort model; this means that it doesn’t guarantee that your traffic will have any specific traffic characteristics between your location and any destination. Because of this, both the Internet and Internet VPN public cloud WAN connection methods would not be able to offer reliable QoS.

questionText: Which cloud service model provides access to an application that is built, monitored, and offered by the cloud provider?
explanation: Software as a Service (SaaS) is likely one of the most publicly used services on the modern Internet. Common examples include iCloud, Google Drive, Dropbox, Office 365, and many more. When using a SaaS, the customer doesn’t need to deal with any hardware or software issues that come up as part of the host system; they only need to handle issues related to the specific service being provided.

questionText: Which option is not one of the most commonly deployed virtualization vendors and products?
explanation: Four of the most commonly deployed virtualization products include Microsoft Hyper-V, VMware vCenter, Citrix Hypervisor (formerly XenServer), and Red Hat Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM). Oracle does create hypervisors, including Oracle VM, but not under the name Oracle vCenter.

questionText: Regarding containers used in server virtualization, which of the following answers lists a software component not typically included in the container?
explanation: A software container relies on an environment that supplies a running Operating System (OS) that includes support for software containers. The container image (the multi-file container as stored on disk) holds the application executable files and any other files the application needs besides those included with the OS. A container may consist of files with application settings and software libraries not included as a standard part of the OS.

questionText: Each virtual OS instance that exists on a server is referred to as a ___________
explanation: In virtualization a virtual machine (VM) is a single instance of an operating system (OS).

questionText: Which cloud service model is primarily targeted toward the software development community and provides the ability to not only customize the hardware being virtualized but also offer different development tools and utilities that are commonly used for a specific environment?
explanation: Platform as a Service (PaaS) is a very popular cloud offering as it provides for a dynamic environment that can be used by developers to both code and test their specific solutions. A common problem before PaaS was that developers had to build specific hardware/software environments that would be used to emulate each specific customer demographic to ensure that their solutions would work correctly. With PaaS, now these environments can be quickly created and be used to test solutions much more efficiently.

questionText: A data center runs some virtual machines (VMs) and some containers. Think about the concept of a VM image as stored on disk, a running VM once it has been started, a container image as stored on disk, and a running container once it has been started. Which answers accurately compare and contrast VMs and containers? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Virtual Machines (VMs) rely on a virtualization system with a hypervisor. The VM includes an installed OS, so starting a VLM includes initializing (booting) the OS. That process relies on the usual computer components: CPU, RAM, disk, and network. The hypervisor virtualizes those computer resources so the VM can be initialized and run.

A container image does not include an OS and does not rely on a virtualization system or hypervisor. Instead, it depends on an OS with container support and a container engine. The container image includes all software components needed to run an application besides the OS. The container engine enables the management of starting and stopping containers.

As for the answers, VMs use a hypervisor, while containers do not, instead using a container engine. Also, initializing a VM includes booting an OS, so starting a VM may take several minutes. Starting a container takes seconds, more like the time taken to start an application.
comments:
Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-009 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

Inline exhibit

answerChoices.Text: VMs typically take more time to initialize than containers.
Container images typically take more space on disk than VM images.
Containers require a hypervisor to create a working environment.
VMs require a hypervisor to create a working environment.

questionText: What is the name of the Cisco product that offers a number of rack-mountable server configurations intended to be used in data centers?
explanation: A few years ago Cisco got into the server hardware market with its Unified Computing System (UCS) that offers a number of different server configuration options that are intended to compete directly with existing server hardware providers.

questionText: Of the different public cloud WAN options, which have quality of service capabilities to ensure end-to-end application requirements?
explanation: Intercloud exchange, Ethernet WAN, and MPLS VPN all have capabilities that provide quality of service. The only options that do not inherently provide any quality of service capabilities are the Internet and Internet VPN. Keep in mind that once your traffic leaves your perimeter into the Internet it is no longer under your control, and you cannot guarantee any QoS requirements.

questionText: Which cloud service is owned and operated by a third party and allows people from a variety of different companies to request and use its resources?
explanation: A private cloud is defined as a service that is private to a single company that owns and operates the infrastructure and includes the people that will be requesting and using the services offered. A public cloud, on the other hand, is a service that is owned and operated by a third party and the people that request and use the service can be from a number of different companies.

questionText: In the virtualization world, the ___________ manages and allocates the host hardware for each VM.
explanation: In the virtualization world, a hypervisor is used to manage and allocate resources from the host hardware as dictated by the settings of any virtual machines (VM).

questionText: An engineer configures a router that formerly had no VRFs to add two VRFs. The configuration also places some interfaces in one VRF and some in another. How many IP routing tables does the router have now?
explanation:
Devices that perform routing - routers and multilayer switches - use virtual routing and forwarding (VRF) instances to create multiple instances of a router within one device. Without VRFs, a router has a single routing table, and the router places all IP routes into one IP routing table. With VRFs, the router creates a routing table for each VRF. Additional configuration can place interfaces into the VRFs so that their connected routes land in the associated per-VRF routing table. The routing protocol configuration can also place routing protocol neighbor relationships into the different VRFs, so routes learned via those neighbors again land in the correct per-VRF routing table.

A router without VRFs has a single IP routing table. Once configured to use VRFs, the router has the original IP routing table (the global routing table) plus one IP routing table per VRF. Interfaces and routing protocol neighbors not placed into a VRF feed their routes into the global routing table.

In this question, with two VRFs, the router has three IP routing tables: one per VRF plus the global routing table.

questionText: Which cloud service model gives a customer complete control over the virtual hardware components, including processor performance, network connectivity, how much memory and storage space is required, and potentially the operating system that is preinstalled?
explanation: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) is one of the easiest-to-understand service models because it is the easiest to relate from physical devices. When utilizing an IaaS service, you specify all of the requirements of the virtual hardware as well as potentially the operating system that can be preinstalled; this is built and network connectivity is provisioned so that access to the service is completed within a very short amount of time.

questionText: What are some of the pieces of information that can be seen on the default client view within the Meraki Dashboard?
explanation: You can see some very helpful pieces of information in the default client view of the Meraki Dashboard. Some key pieces of information include the device status, description, when the device was last seen on the network, the client usage, client operation system, IP address, policy, MAC address, uplink information, and most recent SSID. Topology and Path Visualization are found under Network-wide > Monitor > Topology, not under the default client view.

questionText: Which answers describe how automation impacts network management?
explanation:
The following are the most common benefits of how automation impacts network management:

	
		The use of APIs and data models makes managing a network easier and quicker.
	
		The use of data and controllers makes it possible to automate functions that were not easily automated before.
	
		It simplifies operations, resulting in more consistent configuration and fewer errors.
	
		The ability to have data analytics provides real-time information that can be used to make decisions.
	
		Faster timelines to implement new projects means more tasks can be completed at a faster rate because of automation.
	
		You can use internal and external input to make more accurate decisions, like time of day and resource loads.


	The incorrect answers happen to describe opposite effects from automation rather than the actual effects.

answerChoices.Text: The use of APIs and data models makes managing a network easier and quicker.
The use of data and controllers makes it possible to automate functions that were not easily automated before.
The use of automation slows the timeline for implementing new projects.
The increase in complexity of operations from automation results in a less consistent configuration and more errors in the network.

questionText: What is the name of the protocol that has been developed by the ONF that is used to communicate between an SDN controller and the network devices it controls?
explanation: The first Southbound Interface that was developed for SDN was OpenFlow; it is controlled by the Open Networking Foundation (ONF). It defines a method of communication between the SDN controller and the switches that it will control.

questionText: When would a SOHO device be a perfect fit for an organization?
explanation:
Small office/home office (SOHO) devices are great for locations that don’t need a lot of infrastructure. They might need a handful of ports for 1 to 5 devices or for 1 to 2 users. SOHO devices are perfect for a home office and a small corporate office.

	A SOHO device would not be a valid solution for a company HQ office with 1000 users; there are too many users and requirements. The company HQ office would be better with some sort of tiered infrastructure design.

	A Data Center space would not be a good location to deploy a SOHO device because of all the infrastructure requirements in such a place.

answerChoices.Text: In a Data Center location with no users
In a corporate office that has 1 to 2 users
In a company HQ office with 1000 users

questionText: Which options are actions of the management plane of a networking device?
explanation: Networking devices can be split into three major planes: data, control, and management. The data plane includes the tasks a device takes to forward a message (frame and/or packet); this includes duties like matching and forwarding a packet based on the existing IP routing table or the transmission of a frame based on the existing MAC address tables. The control plane is responsible for guiding the actions of the data plane; this includes finding the route so that it can be inserted into the routing table or learning the MAC addresses that are known on each switch and placing them into the MAC address tables. The management plane is all traffic that is used in the configuration or monitoring of the device itself; this includes protocols like Telnet, Secure Shell (SSH), Syslog, and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

answerChoices.Text: The matching of a packet to forward based on the existing routing table
The discard of a packet because of an ACL rule
The calculation of the best route for a packet
The lookup of a MAC/IP address pair
The alert of an error occurring on an interface
The configuration of a device via its VTY ports

questionText: Of the figures shown, which depicts an accurate Clos Architecture?
explanation:
There are specific requirements for a spine leaf network:

	
		Each leaf switch must connect to every spine switch
	
		Each spine switch must connect to every leaf switch
	
		Leaf switches cannot connect to each other
	
		Spines switches cannot connect to each other
	
		Endpoints connect only to the leaf switches


	Only Topology D meets all these requirements. For the incorrect answers, here are the attributes that make them fail to meet Clos requirements:

	
		Topology A: Neither spine switch connects to all leaf switches.
	
		Topology B: The spines connect to each other, and some leaves connect to each other.
	
		Topology C: Neither spine switch connects to all leaf switches.

questionText: Which protocol(s) does configuration management tools typically use to automate traditional configuration processes?
explanation: There are two correct answers here. Both the NETCONF and RESTCONF protocols are used by typical configuration management tools. BGP and EIGRP are Layer 3 routing protocols and are not used for automation of configuration processes.

questionText: Which options would be used by or are actions of the data plane of a networking device?
explanation: Networking devices can be split into three major planes: data, control, and management. The data plane includes the tasks a device takes to forward a message (frame and/or packet); this includes duties like matching and forwarding a packet based on the existing IP routing table or the transmission of a frame based on the existing MAC address tables. The control plane is responsible for guiding the actions of the data plane; this includes finding the route so that it can be inserted into the routing table or learning the MAC addresses that are known on each switch and placing them into the MAC address tables. The management plane is all traffic that is used in the configuration or monitoring of the device itself; this includes protocols like Telnet, Secure Shell (SSH), Syslog, and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

answerChoices.Text: The matching of a packet to forward based on the existing routing table
The discard of a packet because of an ACL rule
The calculation of the best route for a packet
The lookup of a MAC/IP address pair
The alert of an error occurring on an interface
The configuration of a device via its VTY ports

questionText: When comparing controller-based networks and traditional networks what are some perceived benefits from a controller-based perspective?
explanation:
The following are the most common benefits when comparing controller-based networks with traditional networks from a controller-based perspective:

	
		New operational models that allow for the entire network to be instantiated, and not just a single device at a time
	
		The use of automation through APIs that enable data driven models
	
		The use of APIs to mass-configure network devices, allowing for more consistency and less errors
	
		The use of DevOps approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity


	The other answers, new operational models that allow for a single device to be instantiated with the entire network in mind and the use of legacy approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity, are actually the opposite benefits of a controller-based network.

answerChoices.Text: New operational models that allow the entire network to be instantiated and not just a single device at a time
The use of automation through APIs that enable data-driven models
New operational models that allow for a single device to be instantiated with the entire network in mind
The use of legacy approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity

questionText: In a controller-based network architecture, what is the name of the interface that is used to communicate between the controller and the deployed network devices?
explanation: Since it is typical to have the controllers drawn in diagrams on top of the devices that it controls, the term Southbound Interface was used to reference the connection point between the controller and the devices that it controls. There are a number of different Southbound Interfaces, including purpose-built protocols like OpenFlow or OpFlex and using other more common protocols like Telnet, SSH, or SNMP.

questionText: What are some perceived benefits of controller-based networks as compared to traditional networks?
explanation:
The following are the most common benefits of controller-based networks compared to traditional networks:

	
		New operational models that allow for the entire network to be instantiated, and not just a single device at a time
	
		The use of automation through APIs that enable data-driven models
	
		The use of APIs to mass-configure network devices, allowing for more consistency and fewer errors
	
		The use of DevOps approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity


	The other answers, new operational models that allow for a single device to be instantiated with the entire network in mind and the use of legacy approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity, are actually the opposite of the benefits when comparing controller-based networks with transitional (legacy) networks.

answerChoices.Text: New operational models that allow for a single device to be instantiated with the entire network in mind
The use of APIs to mass-configure network devices, allowing for more consistency and fewer errors
The use of DevOps approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity
The use of legacy approaches in the network to increase efficiency and productivity

questionText: Which type of memory does a switch use to build the MAC address table ?
explanation: The MAC address table uses the ternary content-addressable memory (TCAM). Flash is where the IOS resides. The NVRAM is where the startup-configuration resides. DRAM is where you will find the running-configuration, logs, and so on, which will be lost if the device reboots.

questionText: What is another name for a spine-leaf architecture?
explanation:
A spine-leaf architecture is also called a Clos network, which is the name of one of its creators.

	Routed access is an access layer design that focuses on isolating Layer 2 technologies and relies on an IGP for equal cost multipathing (ECMP).

	VXLAN and Fabric Path are traditionally data center technologies that can be deployed inside a spine-leaf architecture, but they are not a requirement for a spine-leaf architecture.

questionText: Which options are actions of the control plane of a networking device?
explanation: Networking devices can be split into three major planes: data, control, and management. The data plane includes the tasks a device takes to forward a message (frame and/or packet); this includes duties like matching and forwarding a packet based on the existing IP routing table or the transmission of a frame based on the existing MAC address tables. The control plane is responsible for guiding the actions of the data plane; this includes finding the route so that it can be inserted into the routing table or learning the MAC addresses that are known on each switch and placing them into the MAC address tables. The management plane is all traffic that is used in the configuration or monitoring of the device itself; this includes protocols like Telnet, Secure Shell (SSH), Syslog, and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

answerChoices.Text: The matching of a packet to forward based on the existing routing table
The discard of a packet because of an ACL rule
The calculation of the best route for a packet
The lookup of a MAC/IP address pair
The alert of an error occurring on an interface
The configuration of a device via its VTY ports

questionText: In a controller-based network architecture, what is the name of the interface that is used to communicate between the controller and programs wanting to control the flow of traffic?
explanation: In a controller-based network architecture, the controller has its own responsibilities, which align with the duties of common control plane networking protocols like EIGRP, OSPF, and ARP or processes like MAC learning. The controller then uses this information to control the deployed devices via the Southbound Interface (SBI); but the controllers themselves need to be configured as well. This can happen using direct access to the controller or through a number of application programming interfaces (API). These APIs can then be used (via an application) to control how the network forwards the traffic; this interface into the controllers is referred to as the Northbound Interface (NBI).

questionText: When an ASIC needs to perform a lookup on a switch, what is the name of the special type of memory that is used to store the equivalent of the MAC address table?
explanation: Ternary content-addressable memory (TCAM) is used by a switch’s ASIC to perform fast MAC address table lookups.

questionText: Which is true in a spine-leaf architecture?
explanation:
There are specific requirements for a spine leaf network:

	
		Each leaf switch must connect to every spine switch.
	
		Each spine switch must connect to every leaf switch.
	
		Leaf switches cannot connect to each other.
	
		Spine switches cannot connect to each other.
	
		Endpoints connect only to the leaf switches.

answerChoices.Text: Each leaf switch must connect to every spine switch.
Each leaf switch must connect to one spine switch.
Each spine switch must connect to every leaf switch.
Each spine switch must connect to one leaf switch.

questionText: Where does the majority of the switching logic occur on a Cisco switch?
explanation: An application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) is a purpose-built chip that is able to perform message processing at a consistently high rate that is well able what is capable of a switches central processor.

questionText: Which answers describe how automation impacts network management?
explanation:
The following are the most common benefits of how automation impacts network management:

	
		The use of APIs and data models make managing a network easier and quicker
	
		The use of data and controllers makes it possible to automate functions that were not easily automated before
	
		Simplified operations result in more consistent configuration and fewer errors
	
		The capability to have data analytics that provides real-time information that can be used to make decisions
	
		Faster timelines to implement new projects, which means more tasks can be completed at a faster rate
	
		The use of internal and external input to make more accurate decisions, like time of day and resource loads


	The other answers are actually the opposite of the impact automation has on network management.

answerChoices.Text: The use of automation slows the timeline for implementing new projects
Simplified operations result in more consistent configuration and fewer errors
Increase in complexity of operations from automation resulting in a less consistent configuration and more errors in the network
The ability to have data analytics that provides real-time information that can be used to make decisions

questionText: When planning a greenfield Cisco SD-Access design, what traditional LAN design points should be included?
explanation:
When planning a greenfield Cisco SD-Access design, the traditional LAN design points are


	The number of switchports needed in each switch
	The required speed of the switchports
	The benefits of a switch stack in each location
	The current cable lengths and types already used
	The requirement to support power to endpoint devices
	The current power available in each new switch
	Link capacity for links between switches


For the incorrect options, a security firewall to properly segment traffic is actually something that does not help within the LAN portion of Cisco SD-Access.
Also, note that neither the underlay or overlay requires the use of Spanning Tree, so the STP mode need not be consisered.

answerChoices.Text: The number of switchports needed in each switch
The required speed of the switchports
A security firewall to properly segment traffic
The Spanning Tree mode of operation to use

questionText: Which topology in the figure implies a valid Cisco SD-Access routed access layer design?
explanation:
The features of a routed access layer design are:

	
		All switches act as layer 3 switches
	
		All switches use an IGP
	
		All links between switches operate as layer 3 links instead of layer 2 links with trunking.
	
		No VLANs extend beyond a single switch so Spanning Tree Protocol is not needed.
	
		Endpoints use an IP address on their directly-connected switch as their default gateway.
	
		A First Hop Redundancy Protocol (FHRP) is no longer needed.


	Of the three topologies, only topology A shows all layer 3 links between switches.
comments: 4/3/24 Updated SDA to Cisco SD-Access and marked A as the correct answer as it wasn't listed. -JG

questionText: What should not be done when deploying Cisco SD-Access in a brownfield environment?
explanation:
When deploying Cisco SD-Access in a brownfield environment, there will be live production traffic that you won’t want to interrupt or harm during the deployment of Cisco SD-Access. Because of this, Cisco Catalyst Center should not be leveraged to build out the underlay. In a greenfield situation with Cisco SD-Access, you can use Cisco Catalyst Center to automatically build out the underlay.

With a brownfield deployment of Cisco SD-Access, it is critical to make sure that all the devices, new and old, are listed on the Cisco SD-Access compatibility list. In addition, you must make sure your devices are running software levels that are also defined on the compatibility list. Failure to follow the compatibility list can result in future outages or uncertain behavior.

12/29 - disregard Au query

 

4/3/24 Updated SDA to Cisco SD-Access and DNA Center to Cisco Catalyst Center -JG

answerChoices.Text: Using Cisco Catalyst Center to automatically configure the underlay.
Choosing any Cisco switch that supports RSTP.
Choosing switches that are listed on the hardware compatibility list.
Configuring the underlay without Cisco Catalyst Center (that is, manually).

questionText: The Cisco SD-Access design for the access layer is actually a well-known design called a routed access layer design. What are the features of a routed access layer design?
explanation:
The features of a routed access layer design are

	
		All switches act as Layer 3 switches.
	
		All switches use an IGP.
	
		All links between switches act as Layer 3 routed links, not Layer 2 links spanning VLANs.
	
		Because no layer 2 links exist between the switches, switches do not need to use Spanning tree.
	
		Endpoints refer to a default gateway IP address of an interface on the layer 3 switch directly connected to the endpoint device.
	
		A First Hop Redundancy Protocol (FHRP) is no longer needed.


	As for the incorrect answers, a routed access layer design keeps all VLANs within one switch, with no layer 2 trunks, and therefore no Layer 2 loops possible - removing the need for STP. Most switches enable STP by default but in this architecture they are not required and could be turned off.

answerChoices.Text: All links between switches are Layer 2, spanning VLANs.
All links between switches are Layer 3, not Layer 2 links spanning VLANs.
Spanning tree is needed because Layer 2 is spanned.
Spanning tree is not needed because Layer 2 is not being spanned.

questionText: In a Cisco SD-Access overlay network, what is the first step in the sequence of delivering a frame across the network?
explanation: The first fabric edge node to receive the frame encapsulates the frame in a new message using VXLAN and forwards the frame into the fabric. Once the ingress fabric edge node has encapsulated the original frame in VXLAN, the other fabric nodes forward the frame based on the VXLAN tunnel details. The last fabric edge node in the path removes the VXLAN details, which leaves the original frame and then forwards the original frame toward the destination endpoint.

answerChoices.Text: An endpoint sends the frame to a fabric edge node.
Other fabric nodes forward the frame based on VXLAN tunnel details.
The fabric edge node removes VXLAN details.
The fabric edge node encapsulates the frame in VXLAN.

questionText: What are some benefits of a Cisco SD-Access group-based security model?
explanation:
With legacy ACLs and how we as an industry have managed them over the years, there are a lot of inherent management nightmares. For example, ACEs could not be removed because of the potential risk of failure to the entire ACL. New changes add to the current ACL, which ends up being more complicated the longer it gets.

Cisco SD-Access instead uses group-based security with SGTs. Instead of hard coding a security rule in a list like an ACL, you can identify who and what something is, assign a value to it, and then look up that value in a grid or matrix to validate what the user should and shouldn’t be doing. With this new model, there are some huge benefits:


	Each new security requirement can be considered separately from the existing policies.
	Cisco SD-Access (through Cisco Catalyst Center) keeps the security policies clear as a grid of security groups and their allowed access
	As a result, each policy can be removed without affecting another policy.
	The user interface includes note-taking space to track why a policy was created.
	There is proper logging of when the policy is being used and by whom, and when the policy was last used.


For the incorrect answers, first, note that the user interface in Cisco Catalyst Center shows the SGT access policies as a grid, rather than showing the matching logic as compiled into an integrated whole, making it much easier to work with the policies. You can add new SGTs, and set their access rights (permit, deny), without considering any changes to the existing parts of the table.
comments: 4/3/24 Updated SDA to Cisco SD-Access and DNC Center to Cisco Catalyst Center -JG

answerChoices.Text: The security model as seen by engineers combines policies after configuration.
Each new security requirement can be considered separately from existing policies.
Each new security requirement must consider all endpoints and existing security policies.
Each policy can be removed without fear of impacting another policy.

questionText: The Cisco SD-Access underlay uses a well-known design called a routed access layer design. What are the features of a routed access layer design?
explanation:
The features of a routed access layer design are

	
		All switches act as Layer 3 switches.
	
		All switches use an IGP.
	
		All links between switches act as Layer 3 routed links, not Layer 2 links spanning VLANs.
	
		Because no layer 2 links exist between the switches, switches do not need to use Spanning tree.
	
		Endpoints refer to a default gateway IP address of an interface on the layer 3 switch directly connected to the endpoint device.
	
		A First Hop Redundancy Protocol (FHRP) is no longer needed.


	As for the incorrect answers, the border node is not the default gateway for any of the endpoint devices in the fabric. The edge node the endpoint device is connected to is the default gateway. Because of this, there is no need to run an FHRP anymore.
comments:
12/20 -"The short version is that for SDA, any IGP can be used. That mention of IS-IS on page 389 of Volume 2 is in the context of the paragraph that precedes the list, which discusses a greenfield deployment. In that case, DNA-C can choose its preferred features and configuration to create the underlay, which uses IS-IS as the IGP. A brownfield deployment, which means that you begin with a working campus LAN and improve it to support SDA, can use any IGP. So, the more general requirement is IP connectivity, with a preference for using IS-IS if starting from scratch (aka Greenfield.) "

answerChoices.Text: The border node is the default gateway for all endpoint devices.
FHRP is required for default gateway redundancy and is deployed on the border node.
The switch to which an endpoint device physically connects is that device’s default gateway.

questionText: This Cisco SD-Access design uses the 172.16.0.0/12 network for the underlay addressing scheme and 192.168.0.0/16 for the overlay. Which answer lists addresses that could be useful on switches SW1, through SW4, respectively?
explanation: In a Cisco SD-Access fabric, the underlay IP addressing scheme uses a separate IP address space as compared to endpoint devices and the overlay network. The endpoint addresses (like PC1 and PC2 in this question) use addresses from the same address space as the overlay tunnels (address range 192.168.0.0/16 in this question.) The underlay uses addresses from the range 172.16.0.0/12. Also, switches SW2 and SW3, which do not sit at the edge of the network (and are therefore not Fabric Edge or Fabric Border nodes), do not participate in the overlay at all. So, of the four answers, only the correct answer shows all four addresses from the underlay range 172.16.0.0/12. Of the incorrect answers, some list addresses from the overlay address space that would be useful on edge/border nodes SW1 and SW4, but those answers also overlay addresses for switches SW2 and SW3, which do not need addresses in the overlay address space at all.

questionText: Which of the following options are included with a typical underlay configuration for Cisco SD-Access?
explanation: Of the options listed, only IS-IS routing protocol is correct. Remember that with Cisco SD-Access, the underlay network is completely Layer 3 routed access. This means there is no Layer 2, which eliminates RSTP, FHRP, and any Layer 2 links as correct answers.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. After some troubleshooting, you notice that hosts on the 192.168.2.0/24 network cannot connect to any network resources but are able to ping their gateway. According to the configuration, what is the issue?
explanation:
In the OSPF configuration, no network commands match the router's interface in network 192.168.2.0/24 is missing. As a result, OSPF is not enabled on the interface and does not advertise about network 192.168.2.0/24.

	For the incorrect answers:

	
		The router-id command can list any IP address value, whether it exists as an interface IP address on the local router, some other router, or not at all.
	
		For the the router ospf 10 command, the 10 refers to the OSPF Process ID, not an area. Any value between 1 and 65535 is allowed.
	
		The answer about multiple network commands with area 0 parameters is not correct. Those commands assign the matched interfaces to area 0, and as many network commands as necessary can be used to assign different interfaces to area 0.

answerChoices.Text: The list of network commands does not match interface Fa0/1.
The router-id command should not use a number equal to an interface's IP address.
The configuration should list only one network command with area 0 paremeters.
The router ospf 10 command incorrectly refers to area 10 instead of area 0.

questionText: When using Cisco Catalyst Center, what is it called when you are leveraging the REST API or the GUI interface of Cisco Catalyst Center?
explanation: Most of your time as a user of the Cisco SD-Access network will be leveraging the Northbound APIs, which are the REST APIs and the front-end GUI of Cisco Catalyst Center. Telnet, SSH, SNMP, NETCONF, and RESTCONF are all examples of the Southbound APIs, which are ways Cisco Catalyst Center communicates to the network devices that it manages.

questionText: Where in the Cisco SD-Access fabric is the VXLAN tunneling performed?
explanation: The VXLAN tunneling process for encapsulation and de-encapsulation is performed by the ASIC on each switch within the Cisco SD-Access fabric. This is why it is imperative to make sure to utilize the devices on the Cisco SD-Access compatibility list.

questionText: Consider two consecutive REST API calls from a client to a server. Which answer best describes the fact that REST is stateless?
explanation:
REST stateless operation means that the server will not store any data about one API call for use in processing subsequent API calls. As a result, the REST client must send all data relevant to each API call with each call. Each call can include data, encoded as part of the URI path (resource) and parameters (query field).

	Two of the incorrect answers refer to the REST server making use of information gathered in the first API call to process the second, which goes against stateless operation. The other incorrect answer claims that no data can be sent in a REST API call, whereas RESTAPI calls can include data in the parameter (query) field of a URI.

answerChoices.Text: Both REST API calls from the client must include all necessary data along with that one API call.
The second API call can rely on data stored on the server based on the first API call.
The second REST API call can refer to data created by the first API call by including the URI used in the first API call.
Neither REST API call can pass data from the client to the server.

questionText: What does CRUD stand for?
explanation: CRUD is an acronym for the four primary actions an application performs. They are Create, Read, Update, and Delete.

questionText: Which term is commonly used to refer to the “scheme” in a URI, according to REST API documentation and tools?
explanation: The term scheme refers to the protocol or scheme used to access the resource. For example, in the URI https://example.com, “https” is the scheme or protocol that is used for communication. A Parameter or Query field in the URI is used to pass parameters or data to the server. Host:Port refers to the hostname of the application or controller and the port number used to connect. This is also known as the authority field in a URI structure. Finally, the Path field in the URI structure is commonly referred to as the Resource. It identifies the specific resource being accessed on the server.

questionText: From the following options, what are the required REST API attributes?
explanation:
There are six required attributes for REST APIs:

	
		Client/server architecture: REST APIs operate in the client/server model. This means that an application is built with RESTful APIs that act as the server. A client computer or device would make a RESTful API call to the application.
	
		Stateless operation: All of the state for the connections between client and server is actually on the client. The servers do not hold any state for that connection. This is good because it puts less load on the servers so they can process more requests. From a client perspective, the client must be sure to send the necessary information that the server will need to complete the request.
	
		Clear determination of whether a resource can be cached: With REST APIs, servers can cache the most used resources. This is usually used with GET requests. Caching can speed up the operations and the responses to the users.
	
		Uniform interface: In the RESTful world, everything is perceived to be a resource, no matter whether it’s a document, function, method, class, or module. This simple uniformity of interface leads to consistency and rapid deployment of new systems.
	
		Layered system: With REST APIs, you can leverage the single URI to complete any task at hand. In the background you have no idea that the URI you used actually ended up utilizing several servers/services in the back end.
	
		Code on demand: With REST APIs, you can determine what form of data you want back, and not just the values of data. If you want the form of data to be JSON, XML, or YAML, you can specify that. This is still all with a single URI because it’s just a value in the header of the request.


	For the incorrect options, REST APIs do not run in a peer-to-peer architecture and do not leverage a dynamic interface.

answerChoices.Text: Clear determination of whether a resource can be cached
